Title: "Opportunity to work with smart people but poor top management"
Pros: You get the opportunity to work with very smart and talented people at a large company with room to grow. As with any large company, a lot depends on the team you are on. I was fortunate to be on a great team that was managed like a startup within the larger company.
Cons: I was at Yahoo! for 5 years. At the start things were great but the culture took a dive in the last year. This was in large part due to the fact that management encouraged internal competition causing employees to withhold ideas and information in fear others would steal the idea to reap credit. In addition, we had to deal with large egos at the top, often resulting in poor product decision. Yahoo became a top-down organization that in many ways stifled innovation and creative products.
Advice to Management: Work on creating a bottom-up organization to encourage employee engagement, creativity and ultimately build great products.

Advice to Management: All of you quit and make room for people with any training at all.

Title: "Great people culture and perks"
Pros: The benefits at yahoo are second to none. The culture is lively in most offices, Boston and Sunnyvale having some of the best culture. The perks including free lunch, work phones, amazing events, corporate cards, are industry standard or above. Most importantly, the people are what makes any job great. Yahoo has some great talent, approachable leadership, and all around smart people.
Cons: If you're risk averse, like any company in the industry, yahoo goes through a lot of changes like the recent Verizon acquisition. There have been layoffs in 2016, and that can make people uneasy. Additionally, depending on your role, internal career pathing can be difficult.
Advice to Management: Management is excellent, and they are managing through a lot of change. If they stay honest and advocate for their people, that's all anyone can ask for considering things are already excellent.

Title: "Desktop support"
Pros: Great benefits, great working environment,free food.
Cons: not enough recognition throughout the company.
Advice to Management: present opportunities to everyone in every office not just same building elevation.

Title: "Editor"
Pros: Great team; free food; good benefits
Cons: Expected layoffs with Verizon acquisition
Advice to Management: Get it together

Title: "Lacks Management"
Pros: Good work culture, good food
Cons: No strong management. Engineering team dismantling soon.
Advice to Management: Try to retain the talent.

Title: "A good company"
Pros:
Great work culture.
Good team.
Free food
Good balance between work and fun
Cons: More planning would help the company

Title: "Great talent, but lacks great projects"
Pros: There are a lot of smart and talented engineers.
Cons: Towards the end of my time there, you never knew if your project was going to see the light of day. Management stressed very aggressive deadlines on a project that never launched.

Title: "Very Happy"
Pros: I work with very intelligent people who care about what they are producing, writing quality code. They are like a second family and we focus on team efforts.
Cons: It can be disappointing to read news that often suggests that we are failing even as many Yahoo products win awards from third parties for great content and experiences.

Title: "Miserable"
Pros: Benefits generally good and comparable to other tech companies in the area, free food and other perks. Transportation to and from bay area locations, and that's about it.
Cons: Working in constant threat of being laid off any moment, spending more time justifying the work you do (tons of paperwork) and explanations to keep even critical projects alive like fraud and security. No new projects, same old stuff, keep redoing it with fewer and fewer people.
Advice to Management: Remove bureaucracy and senior executives who are constantly trying to look good on paper, instead set innovative direction for the company. Value employees worth and treat them with respect.

Title: "Architect"
Pros: Still an amazing company with a massive user base and plenty of large-scale challenges. Jeff Bonforte is the best SVP you'll ever work for.

Title: "Technical III"

Cons: It is declining. Many people are leaving

Title: "Customer Service"
Pros: I liked the free lunches, snacks and drinks. Yahoo had decent benefits.
Cons: Yahoo recruiters misled me about the position. They left our that we were required to work until 10pm during the week and that we would be required to work weekends and holidays. They embellished the responsibilities of the job, when all I was doing was resetting passwords all day. The Manager was rude & could cared less about the female staff. The Manager inappropriately flirted with many of the male staff.
Advice to Management: Keep an eye on the LaVista office

Title: "great place"
Pros:
Awesome place for software engineers
Interesting projects, very smart colleagues
Cons: clueless upper management, too widespread, too many properties
Advice to Management: Go back to the basics and excel at it.

Title: "Software Development Engineer"
Pros: Good atmosphere, good benefits, good food, good colleagues
Cons: uncertainty of the transaction with Verizon

Title: "Great People, Horrendous Management"
Pros:
Work/Life Balance
Friendly working environment
Competitive cash pay
Cons:
Management team is paralyzed due to CEO's micromanagement, which leads to employees sitting around or never being in the office
In addition, management doesn't speak to each other and many of them are off on their own crusades rather than wait for the CEO to articulate a clear strategy

Title: "Principal Applied Researcher"
Pros:
-Very good mix of research and production
-Published papers and pushed algorithms to production at the same time
Cons:
-lot of uncertainty in the environment with the talk of take over etc, which is what made me move
-Since I left, a lot has happened and I would not recommend friends to go there. It was a great place to work though in the past.

Title: "No Upward Mobility"

Advice to Management: Focus on the work and the people. Not the politics.

Title: "Gobbled up"
Pros: Freedom to take on at will predefined article assignments from Yahoo News, as well as article assignments covering various strata, and to organically create articles for publication across various media.
Cons: Compensation ceiling too low, too many changes and lack of transparency in submission guidelines
Advice to Management: Be more human

Title: "Great place to work for"
Pros:
New Parent Perks.
Salary is very competitive in my market area
Free food
Cons: Uncertainty at the top makes us at the bottom scared

Title: "Finance Manager"
Pros: good compensation, good benefits, flexible hours. and there are variable products to work on.
Cons: people work there are not always nice, some are arrogant but not really hard working. this might explain why Yahoo has so many turbulence in recent years.

Title: "Software Architect"

Title: "Great company a little unstable."

Title: "Makes you feel completely disposable"

Title: "Yahoo Intern"
Pros: Great company benefits, everyone treats each other as equals regardless of standing, very open environment both figuratively and literally. Lots of opportunities to get involved with events around Yahoo and in the community, pretty cool technologies are used in every Yahoo product
Cons: Depending on the team, stability may become something of question with the recent Verizon acquisition; larger Yahoo products should be safe.
Advice to Management: Keep up the good work and thank you for making all your employees (including interns) feel significant even in a company of this size.

Title: "sales"
Pros:
great food
great benefits
good beer mugs
Cons:
too many ceos
middle management top heavy

Title: "Tech Yahoo"
Pros: Free food is very good. Fun place to work if you care about having fun. Otherwise OK. I really like hanging out with friends and colleagues.
Cons: Leadership not good. Especially senior leadership could be better but I do not worry much as long as my paychecks keeps coming.
Advice to Management: Do not sell your souls. Your engineers are really important. Take good care of them. Money is important but at the same time important to take care of employees.

Title: "Great for me"

- Perks/Benefits

Title: "Yahoo Employee"

I miss working with such a bright, talented group. The benefits are amazing.
Cons: Sometimes change is good but with change comes an uneasy work environment. There were times that I felt uneasy about the shape of the company or if the company would last. I had faith in my management but that can only go so far.

Title: "Worked in the University Recruiting team for over 5 years. Focused on hiring engineering students and new college grads."

Title: "Senior Director"
Pros: good company with a lot of opportunity

Title: "software engineer"

Title: "Work Experience at Yahoo!"
Pros: It is amazing to be part of a company like Yahoo. The work culture is very good. The enthusiasm in the people working around is a huge motivator.
Cons: The transition phase of the company is making it difficult to retain talent

Title: "Would you board the Titanic?"
Pros: Free food at the office. Great benefits. A lot of fun parties, free clothes and gifts and fun co-workers. If you get to travel, it's quite lavish. Stay in top hotels, expense your meals, the works.
Cons:
At this point, I do not know why anyone would jump on this sinking ship. This company is failing because they honestly have no idea what their strategy is. Hopefully Verizon can strip them for parts and put them out of their misery or at least lead them in a better direction, because Marissa Mayer and her "e-staff" have epically failed.

The HR and payroll staffs are the worst I have ever come across.

I received positive performance reviews during my time there, but the review practice is really unfair, there is ridiculous red tape for getting promoted and in general, a lot of Silicon Valley rah-rah nonsense.
Advice to Management:
Stop "drinking the kool aid" and find a new position. Check yourself (and your ego) and stop perpetuating ridiculous corporate lingo like:
Drinking the kool aid (haha)
In the weeds
The North Star
Fire Drills
Buy-in
SWAT Team/Tiger Team
Swim Lanes
Bleeding Edge
Ecosystem
Drill Down
Take this offline
Out of pocket

Directors and above are treated like celebrities. Maybe it's a California thing? They do "road shows" (see previous lingo advice) and managers encourage staff to ask questions (any question) for visibility across the company. Other managers take note and report back to your manager on your behavior.

Yahoo = fail. Not much else you can do.

Title: "Purple Haze"

Title: "AE"

Cons: Very poor senior management with lack of direction who define disengenious people. Stay far away from the NYC sales office. Iceberg right ahead!
Advice to Management: Stay the course didn't work out to well in 2014-2016. The company still has layers of management that do NOTHING while their sales team are out fighting for every ad dollar possible. Help your ad sales teams out and develop a real strategy while giving your sales teams better native tools to work with.

Title: "I worked at both Verizon Wireless and Yahoo"
Pros:
- Talented employee base
- Can be a nice environment, once you set in.
Cons:
previously Shareholders, now Verizon
Entrenched mid-management, that seems stuck in a rut
I shudder at a company like Verizon buying Yahoo. IMO it is certainly a new low, with more lows to come.
Advice to Management:
To the entrenched, try picking up some skills and leaving when you still can. If you have a BP problem (yes, you), maybe you should retire, or take a sabbatical. Your bullying ways will reach a crescendo, until you are "told off", a thing waiting to happen since long.
To senior management, if you get good budget, USE it to good effect. Ask for time. Modernize and revamp your products. Make your products more competitive. Ask more time if necessary, but without a revamp, you are just dieing a slow death. If OTOH your sales start picking up again, you have a good chance to ugh! Make a bigger devil out of Verizon. Actually, fat chance with Verizon

Title: "Software Engineer"
Pros: Perks, lots of them. Good work/life balance.
Cons:
Almost everything else. Very poor Upper management. My manager had no clue whatsoever as to how to manage the team. Hardly saw him at work, my teammates used fowl language all the time, very rude and made me feel uncomfortable. The quarterly review is brutal, since my manager has no clue as to what the team is up to, you are at the mercy of coworkers. It doesn't help to work hard and do a good job. Lots of politics, you have to fight for your survival.

I heard last that the perks are going to be cut shortly, so I fail to see how Yahoo can hire any talent given the circumstances.

Lastly, beware of the chaos and commotion that is Yahoo!. You have to be at the edge of your seat everyday, not knowing when the axe falls. I couldn't survive that kind of uncertainty everyday, not knowing what is in store.

The reason behind the hiring is all the attrition. I assume, there are so many open positions because of the numerous people who are leaving voluntarily. Watch out before interviewing and even more before you accept an offer. Moreover, lots of stuff promised on your offer like bonus will depend on the company's perf, and you definitely won't see that money knowing Yahoo!.

Title: "Management"
Pros: Great atmosphere free food free drinks great pay

Title: "Optimization Strategist - Lead/Senior"
Pros: Opportunity to work with large brands, and handle less of the day to day account management tasks.
Cons:
Resistance to doing what's best for the client's business due to quarterly sales goals, depending on the sales person.
Lack of career development outside of sales track, and outside of location focus which shifted depending on the latest ceo. It's modern day, good people can do good work anywhere. But good move in recent years with more competitive hiring overall.
Company-leadership wise, not keeping the ultimate/primary focus on users and product at ALL times. Too many years of letting sales on quarterly goals (specific ad accounts) drive the business - created a downward spiral in search of quick revenue, loss of users, despite owning such a rich content asset.
Advice to Management: Focus on training and development, as well as let go of personal interests when it comes to promoting managers from less popular offices. You lose talent, and limit talent to markets that don't make sense.

Title: "Incredible culture, drive"
Pros: Despite all ongoing issues and media swirl, still a great place to work. Intelligent, driven co-workers. Good pay.
Cons: Too much noise + very hard to compete with Google and Facebook given limited resources and short term revenue focus.
Advice to Management: Advice to whoever the new acquirer may be....don't screw up the ppl. You will need them to succeed.

Title: "VP Engineering"

Cons: Talent is below average and speed is more important than quality.
Advice to Management: Hopefully Verizon culture can influence you in a positive way.

Title: "Great"

Cons: Have a lot of political instability
Advice to Management: Just spend more effort on employees

Title: "Great place to work"

Cons: Higher Management. Lack of smart and flagship products. Far behind in the race. Mixed response on the acquisition by Verizon.
Advice to Management: Wish the acquisition by Verizon would go well.

Title: "Good Environment"
Pros: Good Environment, Nice people, Great perks
Cons: No cons as such working in yahoo

Title: "Great people"

Cons: CEO turmoil, lack of overarching vision and focus, too many things happening at once, spread too thin, lots of redundant efforts
Advice to Management: Lock in on vision and back in the strategy; drive from top down clear focus and what success looks like

Title: "It's a great media company with an emphasis on technology"
Pros: You get to meet lots of talented people; You get to experience the latest technology; Many onsite classes to take at HQ
Cons: Despite everyone works hard to turn around the company, but killer product is hard to come by. It has been constantly interfered by active investors who just want to squeeze out a profit quickly.

Title: "Internal IT Support"
Pros:
Great benefits, good people (until you start getting closer to upper mgmt and execs). Upward trajectory is there *if* you work your butt off -- but still, no guarantees.

Fun culture, especially if you're at the headquarters.

Good name to have on your resume, despite the company's troubles.
Cons:
If you're not already in the department/organization you want to be in, it is VERY difficult to cross over to another. If you're lucky, your manager will have connections to help you network, but you still have to do your own job and cannot fall behind on quarterly goals -- if you do, your ratings suffer. This can cause employees to strive only for better ratings, not necessarily better work.

Quarterly goal structuring (especially in IT) is absurd, with many arbitrary measurements and sub-goals that can easily end up hurting you if you don't write your goals properly before the quarter.

Quarterly/yearly rating system is ridiculous; nobody except Marissa seems to fully understand it or approve of it and she's made it clear that it's not changing anytime soon.

Those at the bottom (Global Service Desk; Customer Care) are still pitifully underpaid. Some new hires -- even contractors -- can be making tens of thousands more than full-timers who have been with the company longer and/or even moved to the headquarters after their office got shuttered. (This knowledge, of course, is NOT transparently known).

As usual, upper management never fully grasps how important the "little people" are, especially those who support their IT infrastructure. They say they do, but at the end of the day, their paychecks are leaps and bounds bigger and nobody is going to do anything to endanger that stability they have "earned." They still view "IT people" as replaceable because there are so many out there who can be hired at any time; however, the less you respect your IT org, the less they will respect you. We may not do "X," but we support EVERYONE who does -- REMEMBER THAT.

Company culture loves to push "transparency," but make no mistake: this is still Corporate America -- if you don't perform a function deemed "essential" to the company (i.e. make money for the company), you will be among the first to be culled when the yearly axe comes down.
Advice to Management:
LISTEN to those below you. You want to be transparent? BE TRANSPARENT. Otherwise, don't advertise it. If you don't walk the walk, people will not follow you and they certainly will not trust you.

Take risks, but not when they could negatively impact the jobs of those who report to you.

Everybody starts at the bottom. If it's been a long time since you started there, do your best to understand what they go through on a daily basis. Take the time to talk to them, one-on-one. Establish trust.

Understand that if your team does not have clear-cut goals that make sense to everyone, with reasonable opportunities to take advantage of, they are not going to care as much about meeting those goals or working harder for promotions and career growth.

Title: "Smart people but poor direction from leadership"
Pros:

Cons:

- Poor middle management and senior leadership. Lack of clear direction was among the causes of attrition.
Advice to Management: Finish the sale process as soon as possible. It will be harder to get things back on track if this process takes too long.

Title: "Great Place!"
Pros: Great spirit and collaboration! Best people in the world.
Cons: Revenue has been flat YOY.

Title: "A great place to learn and work!"
Pros: Overall it's a great place to work. People are friendly and willing to offer help if you have any question.
Cons: People generally don't hangout after work. It's probably because the office location is not close to downtown.
Advice to Management: Leadership team gets too much pressure from the board for short-term revenue. Don't put the company to play a catch-up game. Need more creativity to change the future of the company.

Title: "Senior Manager"
Pros: The benefits, perks, free food, and 401(k) are really good. Got to work on really BIG Data which Yahoo has like non other than maybe Google and Facebook. If you are in the right group, you will be surrounded by really smart people.
Cons:
Why did it take Yahoo management so long to realize to focus on a few products. Legacy tech stacks were dragging down resources and innovation was inhibited.

Yahoo purchased all these great companies but let them die. Good case in point: Flickr could have been Instagram, Messenger could have been all the messenger/chat programs out there.

In addition, Search would still be competitive had they not signed the Microsoft deal. We sold our soul to the devil!

Now that the company is selling its core assets all the top talent is heading for the doors, and what you are left with are second tier talent that have no clue.
Advice to Management: Invest and promote top talent within. Stop promoting people based on seniority and stack ranking.

Title: "Yahoo Company Review - Current State 2016"

Title: "Search Editor III"

Smart and dedicated coworkers
Great benefits

Lack of leadership
Fast changing priorities, no clear direction and continuity

Title: "Great place to intern"

My internship was at a research lab on mobile and Internet technology.

- There were plenty of learning opportunities, not only in the subject matter of my work but in terms of learning how a big Internet company works
- Senior staff were super supportive
- As an intern, I had access to most in-campus benefits (gym, complementary food and snacks, free public transport, city shuttles, etc.). The only exception was the computer gear "vending" machines. But that makes sense.
- Similarly, interns were invited to participate in all company-wide activities.
Cons: None, really. Some months after I left the lab I worked in disappeared. It didn't affect me but it is really sad.

Title: "Great people at the lower levels, complete mess at the top"

Cons: Strategic black hole, Marissa has surrounded herself with sycophantic yes men who get paid a lot of money to agree with everything she says. So many missed opportunities and costly missteps and investments, which could have been avoided if she had had the courage to hire people who were able to coral her musings in to a coherent strategy.

Title: "Associate Account Executive"

Title: "Brand and nostalgia"

Cons: Lack of true leadership and management

Title: "Software developer at Yahoo"
Pros: Great working environment and opportunities to grow.
Cons: Current company situation are making talent to leave

Title: "Senior software quality engineer"
Pros: its a great place to work, lot to learn every day.
Cons: there is northing to say

Title: "Account Director"
Pros: Yahoo has a great culture with A+ benefits (esp for Omaha) and lots of fabulous people but engagement has gone down with poor management (execs and middle mgmt), layoffs, and incessant Wall Street swirl. More and more good people are leaving. Yahoo needs to find out who's buying them, get seriously more organized, and fix morale to prevent any more churn.
Cons: Wall Street uncertainty, disorganization, management/performance rating system, lack of engagement post most recent round of layoffs/restructuring (which is constant)
Advice to Management: Work on improving resources, systems and processes--current systems make being efficient and productive a nightmare. Make sure you are engaging employees beyond compensation, that's not motivating especially in a world of Wall Street uncertainty.

Title: "A failed company"
Pros:
Competitive compensation and perks
Talented people
Cons:
- The company has a lot of bad managers . My last one was a former good engineer who was promoted to be a manager (who probably accepted the position to speed up his green card process and not because he liked) and became a terrible leader, without any kind of people or soft skills. There are also a lot of directors/VPs whose effectiveness is highly questionable, who barely know what's happening at ground level, know a few buzzwords ("automation" is a good one) and that's all.

- The performance evaluation (QPR) is questionable (to say the least). There's no transparency at all. During layoffs, a lot of people with a "exceed expectation" performance was fired. while others with a mediocre performance stayed (probably because they belong to more "strategic" groups)

- Company loves to reinvent wheels. For example, out there people use Docker; most Yahoo properties uses container platform with no cpu or memory isolation very similar to a BSD jail.
Companies use Kubernetes or Fleet, Yahoo uses a proprietary and mediocre platform that probably spent millions to develop it.

- No winner strategy. It changes all the time, btw.
Advice to Management: Stop reinventing wheels. FIre your bad managers (and there a LOT of them).

Title: "Yahoo Review"
Pros:
Benefits-Free gym, food, etc.
Competitive compensation package
Employees are super nice for the most part
Cons: Very unclear future of the company, potentially sounds like it will be sold. Hard to be focused on doing work when future is so up in the air
Advice to Management: Figure out sale of company as soon as possible so it is not hanging over the heads of the employees longer than necessary

Title: "Past its best days"
Pros: Yahoo was a very exciting company to work for a long time ago. Then, it became a reasonably stable place to work for people with families, or a place for new grads or H1Bs to gain some experience. There was new hope with the Alibaba IPO and Marissa for a while, but that has faded.
Cons: Most managers don't have a clue about technical topics. Product Managers have all the control and most technical managers are afraid to stand up to them. They do user testing and then ignore the results until the drop in traffic after the poorly designed or buggy site is launched. Then, it's time to redesign again. Products in this environment end up being second class at best, as we've all seen.

Title: "Best perks and bad work culture"
Pros: Hire good talents, take care of employees/contractor very well (worked at PayPal, Apple and none of them are even close to Yahoo), good food, work is good
Cons: Some of the directors are very pushy, too much of pressure, hire people who are talented but not emotionally intelligent and they are really rude. This attitude is ignored by leaders since they themselves are very rude. The management is more concerned about performance and don't care about people growing together. People are more concerned about their own growth.
Advice to Management: Don't push people to grow individually. Growing as team is very important.

Title: "Do You Yahoo!"
Pros: Great Benefits package and they treat employees well.
Cons: Draconian quarterly QPR process that pits employees against one another.
Advice to Management: The industry is moving away from QPR and forced ranking, it's time to get with the times.

Title: "Racial Discrimination at its finest."
Pros: Cookies on Tuesday. The gym was nice. There were a lot of healthy food options.
Cons: Well Yahoo likes to tout that they have higher diversity numbers than other companies. It might be nice to report that, but they should also report that they also do not treat their black employees the same. I wish i had some great story about how i tried and tried and my manager had a sit down with me to let me know that there were things i had to work on, and at the end of the day, it just wasn't going to work out. But thats not the case....i was 3 times more productive than my peers and yet was let go....i was told that i received coaching......really????? No one said a word to me. Im guessing that must be the policy and someone was trying to cover their tracks when they fired the only black female on the team that was clearly a high perfomer. I would have loved coaching! I asked to be shown this "review" i allegedly received.....turns out it never existed....to add insult to injury.....i was also told that i made a comment..... the comment that i supposedly made....no one ever heard me say it, and again no one let me know about it. Why would there be sooo many lies about me....with not one shred of proof. Well the great thing is, the department i was in, no has less than 1% African Americans. How about that for diversity!
Advice to Management: If you are going to fire black people, do it based on merit and not skin color. If your policy is to perform reviews and give coaching before letting someone go, make sure this policy is followed for black employees as well. Discrimination and defamation are not whar you want to show in your "diversity" reports that you want to be sooo proud of. And if a black person is going above and beyond, praise them, not let people try to get rid of them with flimsy excuses and lies.

Title: "Great company. Great people. Could be a great product."

Cons: The engineering team doesn't always have things fully baked before higher ups want it released. This makes good products get bad reputations and tarnishes what could have been.
Advice to Management: When things are fully baked, you get much better results and people know they can trust you. Facebook only gets away with it because competition is scarce. When you are in an industry with lots of competition, you need to make sure your product passes every test before its released. Think of Apple's reputation. Yahoo needs to be more like Apple and less like Facebook.

Title: "An epic clusterf**k"
Pros: Good benefits, competitive salaries, some nice perks. The offices are nice, the food is good (or at least it used to be).
Cons: The level of incompetence and bureaucratic dysfunction is mind boggling. It's like they recruited the top level of management directly out of Clown College. People in senior management leave and never get replaced; their direct reports hang around waiting for a new manager or at least some marching orders, but none arrive, so either they rest and vest or they get bored and leave. The organization is highly silo'd; the engineers don't talk to the marketing or media people and no one understands each other. There is no chief operating officer who can make these factions work together, so they end up working against each other -- thus explaining why Yahoo cannot get out of its own way. And the HR process is a disaster; it takes months and months to approve a single hire.
Advice to Management: Just give up. Sell the thing to someone with at least an outside chance of running a competent organization.

Title: "My Dream Company"
Pros:
Yahoo had been my dream company since I met my first Yahoo sales reps as an intern at an online ad agency. I saw how insightful, professional, and knowledgeable these Yahoos were, and as a struggling intern at the time, brand new to Search, I instantly wanted to become like those wonderful Yahoos. At my next ad agency in a different part of the country, the Yahoo team worked even more closely with ours, confirming to me that there was a common value shared among Yahoos all over the world. I knew I had to come here myself when it came time for my next challenge. It was the Yahoo team that taught me about how to succeed in a changing marketplace, demonstrated exceptional customer service, and made me proud to eventually get a job on the vendor side. Yahoo reps roll up our sleeves and teach our clients, we empower them to be self-sufficient in our platforms, and customize trainings to help them succeed. If you care about your work, you will feel recognized and supported at Yahoo by your peers and managers, too.

Yahoo is one of the most generous, fun companies I have ever worked. The most important difference about my day-to-day coming from the agency side, was new autonomy--not a single soul micromanaged me in my 16 months at Yahoo. There was also no drama within my teams. I was given creative freedom to drive the businesses in my portfolio to fit my clients' needs and had a strong, capable, efficient support team of Ad Ops and Creative Strategists to grow those businesses. I was given responsibilities to strengthen my insecurities and had 1:1 with my manager weekly throughout the course of my Yahoo life. I had time in weekly team meetings to ask questions, present wins and challenges, and make an impact for my peers. My ideas were valued from Day 1, and even only after 7 months of work, I had the chance to apply and was selected to fly to London for a Global Exchange program. I worked in the Yahoo UK office for 3 weeks, which was not only a significant career booster, but yet another personal accomplishment I had dreamed of for years. I don't know any other company that would support such an initiative for a relative newbie.

I wish this unique company the absolute very best. Despite the difficult press and evident struggles, Yahoo is a company that most consumers have a soft spot for--many grew up with Yahoo products and don't want to see it fail.
Cons:
I was cut in the latest round of lay-offs, along with 90 others in my role.

Regardless, the folks working at Yahoo are true believers of Yahoo products; we even used Yahoo mail for corporate communications --a frequent pain point-- (no Outlook/calendar), but were also using integrated Google tools on a daily basis. Some may find it difficult or cumbersome to adapt to these tools, but the overall culture and people that work here make it all worth it.
Advice to Management: Listen to the honest updates from your Sales team, which has direct communication and real-time feedback from clients. It is difficult to pitch products that continue encountering problems after leaving the beta mode. When products glitch, it is our integrity and personal reputation that customers begin doubting, which makes it difficult to rebuild relationships or grow business. Regardless, I am grateful for the opportunity and appreciate the generosity shown to me by my employer, managers and peers. G-d bless.

Title: "Stop listening to activists!"

I worked with the nicest, most helpful, and most collaborative people in my career. There are many smart people are willing to explain things, work with you, and generally help, which also feels great.

The perks at HQ are very nice. The gym, free food, and plentiful events keep you going. The free shuttle bus made my commute possible.

Top management makes a big show of being transparent, and tries to keep the employee base informed of what's going on.
Cons:
Everyone has heard of Yahoo, and many people have negative opinions that they are eager to share. This extends to the media. Heck, it starts in the media.

The bench seating undeniably removes barriers to collaborations. Your co-workers are right on top of you! It is distracting and requires much mental effort to handle. I would rather spend my mental energy creating better solutions.
Advice to Management: Please stop listening to loud minority investors. This is probably aimed more at the board of directors, then company officers.

Title: "The best job you'll be happy to leave"
Pros: You'll work alongside bright, talented and ambitious peers who often see the big picture and have good instincts on how to achieve success when faced with significant obstacles.
Cons: The bane of Yahoo! is senior management. They're a tribe of executive nomads who roam between companies looking to loot as much as possible until they either leave of their own accord or are forced out. I attended a company all-hands meeting once where a brave soul stood up and verbalized what I held inside for the better part of 5 years... at Yahoo!, the only criteria for strategic direction is that it be significantly differentiated from that of the former regime. Plenty of accountability at the lower levels, but executive management gets endless free passes.
Advice to Management: Please resign and suggest to the BOD that a "promote from within" policy be instituted for a minimum of 2 years until the company can course correct. The worker bees know how to create amazing content, they just need senior management to be pushed aside.

Title: "Software Engineer"

Title: "Great company, great people!"

Title: "Rearranging furniture on the Titanic"
Pros:
Best place I've worked at so far

Excellent benefits

Competitive salary and bonuses

Free breakfast / lunch / dinner

Free coffee / juice bars all day

Excellent networking opportunities since many ex-yahoos go to LinkedIn / Google / Facebook / Apple

Since the company has been around for 20+ years, it's a great place to learn what works and what does not

Macs everywhere, no Windows

2 factor auth system is seamless

Enormous scale - your work can affect millions of people daily
Cons:
No company is perfect, definitely not this one

Constant looming fear of layoffs

Endless negative press

High attrition due to the above 2 cons

SO MANY POINTLESS MIGRATIONS... one quarter it's migrate to this, next quarter it's migrate to that, next quarter the team maintaining that platform is either laid off or bails to another company because they are tired of this BS, next quarter it's migrate to another platform because nobody is maintaining the last one. Repeat.

Many of the internal services are extremely unstable and are not treated with the same respect as a production service. This has resulted in a large portion of the company using services like slack because we can't keep our own damn internal messaging services online.

Recruiters will spam your inbox, even your work inbox... and don't even think of answering your phone. I seriously cannot answer my phone anymore.

ESPP was discontinued about a year ago and replaced with stock grants that have lost 50% in value and take forever to fully vest

Stock price is tanking with no end in sight

Direction and future of company is unclear. Facebook / Google are leeching all of the ad revenue and ad-block software is reducing it

Management fails to see the harm QPR is causing to the company.

You will only receive high ratings if your projects are in the spotlight. This means if you end up with a streak of un-sexy projects for multiple quarters, you are at risk of being fired. The number of people that can receive a high rating is extremely limited. This means if you have a team of 10 world class engineers, only 1 would get the highest rating, 2 would get the next highest, and everyone else would be rated "average". This is extremely demotivating and causes high performing engineers to leave the company and go somewhere they can be property recognized.
Advice to Management:
QPR is killing the company. Remove this policy and don't look back.

Take a survey of users and ask what Yahoo properties they know about. Shut down everything that is rarely named.

Invest employees from the failed properties into ones that matter.

We only need one or two major offices in each region of the world, close all of the others and be done with layoffs for the next 5-10 years.

Spin off the BABA stake faster, nobody wants to wait another year.

Do these things and our company will be extremely profitable

Title: "Great Culture but has Lost its Focus on Core Competencies"

Advice to Management: Get back to basics and focus on what made Yahoo great: Sports, Mail, Finance and Weather... Continue to focus on Mobile but trim the fat and update your infrastructure...

Title: "Yahoo review"

Title: "A micromanagement hell & innovation stifler."
Pros: Smart, fun people abound. Free food is great. Benefits are pretty awesome.
Cons: Micromanagement is unbearable. Innovation is completely stifled by process and QPR system. Almost zero focus exists across the board and strategies change monthly. Reorgs happen like clockwork every 6-8 months. CEO is way too involved in day-to-day. Resources are regularly shifted into really terrible projects that are abandoned a year later.
Advice to Management: Trust the experts you hire to do their jobs. Eliminate the cutthroat culture that encourages every employee to attempt to take the reigns of every project - this ends up creating too many cooks in the kitchen. Stop C-levels from wasting time analyzing minute details like the logo placement on a sign at an event. Remember your corporate name is literally an expression of frivolity and joy - stop trying to make it stale and staid.

Title: "Great place to work"

Title: "Learn everything!"
Pros:
The APM Program at Yahoo is the best place to become an exceptional Product Manager. We get a solid foundational introduction the first few weeks, and begin our projects right away. It's a bit intimidating at first the level of responsibility you're given, but it's awesome. I meet with my manager regularly, have a few mentors who have helped provide additional perspective, and an executive coach who works with me on developing my leadership style, communication skills, and anything else I need help with.

Throughout the year, we have chats with SVPs, Design directors, Architects, and other teams such as the Accessibility Labs and User Research groups, to learn more about what they consider / how they approach product. We have outings and fun events with our class and other APMs. We also went on a 2wk international trip to study tech markets in Israel and Asia, specifically focusing on how tech is created & consumed in those regions by speaking with venture firms, startups, tech policy makers, and university research labs.

There is a lot of change, and keeping up with it can sometimes be challenging. However, I've found that this has helped me work more flexibly, so I'd consider it both a pro and a con. Yahoo can only grow as quickly as it has if there is constant transformation, which requires change as the company evolves. It's a special time in the company's history to be here, and it's cool that my work has such a large impact!

If you want to be challenged to do great things with the support system of champions, the Yahoo APM Program is the place to be.
Cons: Constant change = a pro and a con.

Title: "love it love it"

Cons: But it’s not just about the paycheck. Work makes people happier. If you’re a person with a disability and are thinking about work, there is something you should know: People with disabilities who work are healthier and happier than people with disabilities who are unemployed.

Significant barriers to employment still exist, but progress is being made. Individuals with even the most severe disabilities have shown that they can be successful at work, changing their lives and changing the way people with disabilities are viewed in society.

Title: "Working at Yahoo!"

Title: "Fun but Fake"

Narrow minded managers who've never worked at a better or differently managed company, many of whom have never worked at any other company period, so honestly probably just don't know any better. Too much time by just about everyone on self promotion, often based on inaccurate or outright false data. Desperate managers so afraid to leave their cozy nest that they generate ridiculous efforts just to toot their own horn, with little or no regards for the actual financial or humane value. Lack of work life balance except for those either skilled in deception or too workaholic to need an outside life. Coworkers so eager to please they'll go along with any harebrained management request at the drop of a hat.
Advice to Management: Not everyone believes the spin. Have the respect to be honest with those seasoned and savvy enough to see through the smoke screen. You may be able to fool the naive, but don't think everyone is clueless enough to buy into the propaganda. Don't force them to pretend. Grow some humility. It's a nice company but it's hardly Utopia. Remember you are a human being first, and a Yahoo employee second, as are your employees, clients and colleagues.

Title: "Learn the business"
Pros: good smart people to learn internet industry and develop career. need to find opportunities but can add value to businesses
Cons: PC based business can be tough as things move to mobile. typical corporate politics play a role in responsibilities and roles
Advice to Management: figure out strategy and go for it

Title: "Positive experience"
Pros: I had some good experience and learned a lot from the industry
Cons: The company was large and difficult to find position advancements

Title: "Director Program Management"
Pros: Nice food, flexibility, smart people
Cons: Sometimes too political, Process too heavy, Top heavy

Title: "software engineer"
Pros: free food,free phone. nothing else really.
Cons: managers don't understand technologies, purely doing people management. Profit driven , don't care about user experience!
Advice to Management: while you are hiring like crazy, try to understand why people leaving!

Title: "Overall, good place to work"
Pros: Great people, collaborative environment, opportunity for advancement
Cons: executives departures harm stability of work force
Advice to Management: Focus, Agile Decision-Making

Title: "Meh...."
Pros: Good people free food great work environment work life balance
Cons: Quarterly performance reviews, hiring is a huge churn and time suck. Executive leadership changes often directions change often
Advice to Management: get ride of QPR

Title: "Sr Mgr"
Pros: free food and good hardware/computers and free phones
Cons: bureaucracy and red tape and
Advice to Management: pb&j

Title: "In transition"
Pros: Good tech learning environment. Company is trying hard to succeed.
Cons: Too much work and very frequent changes makes it hard to keep work and life balance. Quarterly review adds more mental pressure.

Title: "Sales"
Pros:
Great Atmosphere
Great Sales
Good company
Great people
great management
Cons:
Huge company
hard to move up

Title: "Good company to work, but no good product"
Pros: Company treats employee well, offer free food, have good summer picnic and holiday party, free medical plan when I joined in 2004.
Cons: no good product, sales drops, bad managements and headship, some politics, too many layers in management structure. company needs to layout employees.
Advice to Management: Find good CEO to turn company

Title: "Product improving, but outlook isn't"
Pros: Lots of new and improved products. Good energy and nice perks (free food). A feeling that we're working on something important (even though the rest of the world disagrees)
Cons: Too many leaders in senior roles that shouldn't be. Yahoo has all these Directors who are basically just front-line managers (no manager reports). Trying to retain by giving inflated titles is a sign of desperation..
Advice to Management: Make the company's focus on Tumblr. At least the kids use that product (thanks to all the porn). The brand of Yahoo is ignored by anyone younger than 40.

Title: "It really depends on the team.."
Pros: Free food, events for employees and families
Cons: Quarterly performance goals & reviews, hiring process takes long time, no ESPP

Title: "Good company bad management"
Pros: I really had a good time working for yahoo. Folks were talented.
Cons: Unfortunately management took it down the drain.
Advice to Management: Clear direction and more collaboration

Title: "Sr. Manager, Account Management"
Pros:
Amazing culture and even more amazing people!
Large, loyal user base
Awesome benefits and very competitive pay
Cons: Once you are a manager, it's difficult to get promoted after that; folks in those Director+ roles tend to stay for years, blocking upward mobility to others.

Title: "Great company"
Pros: Free food, love the tech culture
Cons: Free food, Office in Times Square

Title: "They look after you.."
Pros: Lots of perks and benefits! Just like the googles and the faceboobs..
Cons: They lay people off quite regularly, even though they stopped for a while, they're back at it!
Advice to Management: Good luck, we're all counting on you.

Title: "A giant full of politics"
Pros:
The perks are pretty awesome. Free gym, food, phone, shuttle, swag, events, sport courts.

Culture is still good and there is still some great engineers that are going to teach you lots of cool stuff.
Cons:
The easiest way to get a promotion or a raise is by leaving the company for some time and come back as a new hire. Or work 14 hours a day and suck your manager's balls.

Yahoo is bleeding talents. And the VPs/Directors fight for power and don't collaborate. It is not uncommon to see two different orgs building the same product instead of collaborating.

Title: "software engineer"
Pros: 1. Great minds at work, 2. Lots of opportunity to work on big data, distributed systems. 3. Fast pace , latest technologies in use. 4. Open culture , fun events and great work life balance as well.
Cons: Need more focus on improving the quality of products across different verticals and keeping customer experience at center.
Advice to Management: With large value of Alibaba stake attached to Yahoo stock, sometimes the hardwork does not get noticed on stock value.

Pros: Interesting work. Opportunity to work with some nice people. Good food and coffee.
Cons: Management is not transparent, open or honest and it lacks integrity about managing performance. Unfortunately, decisions were made to manage people out of the company when truly they should have stated they needed to layoff employees to meet business needs. Many employees work smart and they are intelligent and bright. Contributing performers were told they did not meet Yahoo's performance standards when in reality they did. They just weren't political enough to hold onto their jobs or steps on their coworkers' toes to save their jobs in order to get ahead. While Yahoo focuses on analytics they forgot how to treat people with respect, dignity and with human kindness. It is a Company who wants to delight and entertain it's customers but forgot how to treat their most valuable assets - their employees.
Advice to Management: Desire greatness by remembering their employees and their daily unnoticeable sacrafices that contributes to Yahoo being successful.

Title: "Worst Run Company Ever"
Pros: Lots of exposure to various projects and experiences that help you grow and develop rapidly.
Cons: Disorganized, dysfunctional at every level but mostly at the executive level of the company, lack of strategy, and bureaucratic.
Advice to Management: Find a new CEO that is experienced.

Title: "Software Intern"
Pros: Amazing stuff going on. Totally recommend
Cons: Intern housing instead of asking us find one ourselves would be better
Advice to Management: Free food, lots of fun activities, many outings. Cant ask for more.

Title: "Not the worst, but far from the best"
Pros: good health and education benefits, flexible work schedule
Cons: low and stagnant wages, little future career growth (unless willing to move to Sunnyvale or wait out for a position in lower level management)
Advice to Management: invest more in your people, both financially and morally.

Title: "Some good, some less good"
Pros: Health insurance & benefits; free food; free iPhones; nice new laptops; nice offices; excellent benefits for LGBTQ employees; maternity leave & adoption leave policies; relatively transparent top execs; flexible scheduling; lots of vacation hours that roll over at end of year.
Cons:
bureaucratic hurdles from size & sprawl of different divisions; challenging performance review process; quickly shifting priorities; way way waaaaayyyyy too many directors, Sr. directors, and VPs clogging up the upper middle of the org structure and making operations difficult.
In those below executive level, there is Widespread lack of trust in the top execs, with the exception of CEO.
Advice to Management: Try being like "undercover boss" for a couple days and find out how your divisions are being run at the lower levels! Many of your goals are mistranslated as they filter down to middle managers - leads to a lot of confusion and wasted work time.

Title: "Slowly but surely"
Pros: Great collaboration and friendly employess.
Cons: Not really sure where the company is going. Feels stagnant in terms of monetization and growth.

Title: "Human Resources"
Pros: Always changing, dynamic, learned a ton
Cons: Almost too much change, hard to be strategic
Advice to Management: I hope you are successful! Love the brand, great people

Title: "Good"
Pros: free food, great people, fun team activities
Cons: pay, slow to move up

Title: "No clear vision"
Pros:
1. Awesome work place
2. Great benefits
3. Smart and talented work force
Cons:
1. Vision is not clear
2. Fails at attracting new users

Title: "Working at Yahoo (Sunnyvale) as a creative designer"
Pros:
-Work alongside some of the brightest talents out there.
-The benefits are great.
-The pay is competitive.
-The experience offers exciting challenges.
-The corporate exposure to other competitors.
Cons:
-Shortsighted in marketing strategies.
-The creative ceiling has a limit...creative strategies can get stagnate.
-get ready to lose your social life, as it mainly resides on their campus.
-The Silicon Valley as a location to live is a bit depressing as well as the cost of housing...rentals or owned.
-Quick turnover of employees.
Advice to Management: Listen to the creative geniuses you hire and try implementing their new ideas.

Title: "Tons of Talent, Buried under Piles of Risk Averse Management"
Pros: Great perks, offices, and good people. Technical solid. Great innovation exists in those walls.
Cons: Amazing engineering talent, unfortunately all scattered about, working on multiple competing projects, sitting on a stack of 15 year old legacy code. Change requires almost direct line up to Filo, with teams projects often getting scuttled for no reason, or timelines that are just incredibly long winded and surrounded by layers of management
Advice to Management: Let the innovation flags fly, and tell management to get out of the way.

Title: "Great place to work and prosper"
Pros:
Good opportunity to pursue one's desire
Open platform to communicate with senior management
Good perks and benefits
Excellent work-life balance (at least in my group)
Cons:
If stuck in a group with polarizing priorities then glass ceiling is inevitable. May be that is the same with any enterprise. Creativity and assertiveness may pave the way.
Most of the time if major shake-up is on its way, it could hit you like lightning. I've gone through 3 lay-off and rehire before the termination date. No complaint - every time it is a wake-up call to reality and psych up my survival skill.
Advice to Management: QPR is a great sucker of everyone energy and motivation. When many companies are shying away due to lack of its effectiveness, do you still believe it is working for you?

Title: "Fun place to work"
Pros: Coworkers are great. Work on things that hit lots of eyeballs. Good engineering backbone. Treat employees pretty well.
Cons: A lot of politics. Infighting. The usual corporate bureaucracy.

Title: "Senior Software Engineer"
Pros: Good benefits. Subsidized cafeteria. Looks good on a resume.
Cons: Constant reorgs. No clear direction.

Title: "Lack of focus, hard to see results"
Pros: Legendary brand, great benefits, awesome work environment/apple devices. Smart and hard working people.
Cons: Too hard to get in front of young generation, too big to keep up the game in the industry. Lack of focus, lack of the killer product/service. Everyone tries very hard, but slow to see results. Too many layers, slow to get things done. Too many changes in leadership that various teams don't have clear responsibilities.
Advice to Management: Don't try too many things at the same time. Should cut products that's not profitable and have the WHOLE company focus on one thing/direction.

Title: "Experience working full time"
Pros: culture, work quality, people,location, flexibility
Cons: Fading away when compared to other giants and small companies coming up in the tech scene. If you wana be on top of the tide, this is an option for sure but not your first option.
Advice to Management: Doing great. No advice

Title: "Good company"
Pros: The salary was decent there.
Cons: Management obviously needs improving there.

Title: "sr. principal engineer"
Pros: excellent pay, benefits. flexible working policy.
Cons: rudderless direction; no investment in technology
Advice to Management: stop retrofitting existing solutions to new usecases and invest for the future.

Title: "principal software engineer"
Pros: get good experience to learn big data
Cons: unclear company vision, review rating by quarter

Title: "Great Company, Suspect Future"
Pros: Great benefits, Good Pay, Opportunities to work on web scale problems, Work with really smart folks
Cons: Future of Yahoo is suspect

Title: "yahoo US"
Pros: very talented co-workers. Learned a lot from my co-worker and manager. Nice culture. Good work life balance. Free coffee bar sponsored by the founders.
Cons: sometimes things move slowly. You don't get opportunity to work on different projects and you may get bored working on the same thing forever.
Advice to Management: Provide flexibility of switching from project to project so employees get excited and challenged on new stuff.

Title: "Great Perks and Balance"
Pros: Love the perks in the Sunnyvale HQ - great food, lots of fun events (octoberfest, concerts on the quad, etc). They treat you very well while you are there and have pretty good work/life balance, especially for parents that can't stay late everyday due to family obligations.
Cons: Company is too large, so it's hard to make big contributions as an individual.

Title: "Yahoo review"

The benefits package is fantastic.
Obviously the free food & other perks are a draw as well.
Cons:
Everything is politically charged & favorites are sometimes played.
The QPR process has wreaked havoc on the culture and on morale.
The hiring process is painful for those hiring & those being hired.
Advice to Management: Spend some time looking at the middle management and focus on developing them into strong leaders.

Title: "Not innovative"
Pros: Free food and free phones.
Cons: Lots of politics, and the CEO that bottlenecks everyone, doing minor pixel changes. Yahoo needs a new leader with actual vision, not another pixel pusher.
Advice to Management: Get rid of Marissa Mayer and get a real CEO. And kick out the lifers. Many of them are poor performers who get by through kissing up and playing politics, not actually doing anything.

Title: "good place"
Pros: Overall, it's a good place to build and grow in your career
Cons: Generally it has been unstable due to well known reasons
Advice to Management: clear focussed goals and alignment to needs of consumer will help

Title: "Great place to work at!!"
Pros:

Cons: There are none I believe!!

Title: "SWE"

Cons: Long working hours, but feels good

Title: "overall very good company and work atmosphere"

definitely a good work environment. i was able to work alone and never in 3-4 yrs felt any pressure to do my job, i just did it.
sometimes i miss the place
Cons:
i worked there at a time before marissa got there and there was a shuffle of a few different CEOs.
so there was definitely a lack of guidance from CEO level, and there were some bad acquisitions by the company.
at the time, because positions were limited in the area, there wasn't much room for any sort of advancement unless i was willing to relocate
Advice to Management:
none.
i imagine current CEO has things on track.

Title: "working experience"
Pros: It's good for a new graduate students. Good learning opportunity, nice people to work with and very good food for employees.
Cons: Not much challenge. Management and organization is not so good.

Title: "Sen Software Engineer"
Pros: Great place to work, full freedom
Cons: RSU/shares keep moving up and down. :-)

Title: "Strong Upward Mobility"
Pros: Executives are very approachable and open to suggestions. Many chances to rise in the company due to regular reshuffling and departures. Easy to shine if you do great work. Easy to make big impact. Colleagues are friendly.
Cons: Morale isn't the highest, especially after layoffs. Engineering practices are behind the norm, but they're working on it. Quality is often lacking in products. Company focus is unclear, and changes regularly. Lots of thrashing in orgs like talent. Future is uncertain, so often the focus is very short term.
Advice to Management: Internal mobility is unnecessarily painful.

Title: "Great Culture, Hard Workers"
Pros:
Yahoo has a fantastic culture and management actually cares about your well-being. I have never felt unwanted.

The work you will do needs a lot of focus and thinking outside the box. It will challenge you every day, but in a good way! I have grown so much in my short time here!
Cons:
The work load can get pretty crazy. Managers recognize it and try to minimize it, but just because of how the company is right now, it's a ton of work!

Working with engineers can be frustrating, they build products how they think they should function, when they aren't the ones using the tools every day!
Advice to Management: Get the day-to-day people involved more on the building of tools. It will cause it to be streamlined more rather than having to go back and fix it.

Title: "Senior Program Manager"
Pros: Yahoo has been a remains a great environment to work with some of the smartest talent. There was great team cooperation and willingness to go the extra mile for your colleagues.
Cons: Lack of a clear vision that will turn the company around. Market perception remains negative unless company can find a way to grow revenues and profits.
Advice to Management: Drive more decision making power down to the teams. Let teams have the autonomy to conceive and bring to market their ideas.

Title: "Very disorganized, low morale when I was there (2011)"
Pros: They had some great perks and you get a chance to solve problems on a very large scale. I got some exposure to exciting open source projects.
Cons: Very disorganized and very low morale. There were huge layoffs while I was there, and one of the founders left. It was a rough time for Yahoo! Also, although they embrace open source, a lot of tools that are critical were forks of open source things that were poorly maintained or quickly abandoned. Some of the more mature forks developed into basically proprietary tools, with little, or poor documentation. There was a lot of out for number 1 and teamwork was lacking. Many teams did basically the same thing and didn't even know their counterpart teams existed (including mine).
Advice to Management: Give people more time, less meetings. Embrace new ideas, and don't kill projects in the name of pleasing shareholders. So many changes in direction was wasteful, and Yahoo! paid a high price for that. It seems like things are much better now, under Mayer, but while I was there, there were to many bosses, not enough workers, and too much power struggle and politics. It really overshadowed the reasons I wanted to be there.

Title: "Customer Experience"
Pros: Learn a lot of life skills. good training and fun environment
Cons: Lot of angry customers during phone calls. But you get training
Advice to Management: CHange up the work..same work got boring

Title: "support"
Pros: Not from that position. None that I can think of. Some decent people on my same level, not many above me.
Cons: under pay, long times to promotion if at all, too much internal politics.

Title: "Good window-dressing, but poor management and job security"
Pros: Free stuff: food, coffee, snacks, movies, concerts, shuttles, and some very friendly employees. Best for SW engineers.
Cons: Quarterly, stacked ranking reviews have intensified the "watching one's own back" and micromanagement and quarterly terminations along with the ongoing layoffs. Transfers and advancement is possible if you brown-nose with the right higher-level managers, but opportunities to learn and grow aren't available, especially if you don't have CS degree or Masters. Management/people skills are not valued there;and some managers like to yell and swear at employees during meetings and bully during 1:1s because they lack these skills, yet they often get promoted.
Advice to Management: Practice what you preach by also requiring CS degrees of your executive staff and valuing and promoting the good managers and firing the bad ones as you said you would do based on employee surveys. And be above board about your constant layoffs. Remember that the good employees find better jobs because they can, leaving you with only the average or mediocre ones who have gotten complacent.

Title: "Good"
Pros: Really cool and friendly environment to work at
Cons: The company is sinking in the recent past.
Advice to Management: Please come up with a new idea to bring back the company on track

Title: "Great place to work!"
Pros: I had a really good time working for Yahoo! Smart people and a great environment.
Cons: I have heard from several former employees and discovered for myself that you don't know how great the company is until you're gone.

Title: "Good place to work, but the media bashing is tiring"
Pros: Free food, phone, good work environment, wide range of products/technology, talented and intelligent co-workers.
Cons: Bad media image, sometimes the quarterly/annual review process is tedious.

Title: "Good Company"
Pros: Nice people! Good work environment .
Cons: Overworked in every area of the company.
Advice to Management: treat people equally!

Title: "None"
Pros: Free food, Good benefits, great atmosphere
Cons: Lack in quickness to market.

Title: "Director"
Pros: Empowerment to drive initiatives. Challenges that come with scale. A lot to learn. Global reach for the products you work on. Opportunity to grow. Competitive Salary.
Cons: Beaurocracy. Good leadership scarce so you may feel lost without it.

Title: "Respectable tech company"
Pros: This was one of the best companies I ever worked for. The benefits and perks, which include a few paid weeks of paternity / maternity leave as well as one's own laptop along with smartphone among other things, were very generous. Salaries and compensations were also highly competitive and slightly above market rate.
Cons: The selection process is very competitive and onboarding can be arduous and protracted as well; therefore patience is in order. Additionally, once hired into a role, movement in terms of promotion (especially vertical moves) proved a little challenging.

Title: "Average"
Pros: Management could work on being more in tune with employees.
Cons: Performance reviews too frequent, and are not good gauge of company talent.

Title: "Principal Software Engineer"
Pros: free food, compensation, good engineers
Cons: Politics, QPR, hidden layoffs, unprofessional management
Advice to Management: to replace management

Title: "Amazing"

amazing work culture
lots of interesting challenges to deal with
Cons:
lack of innovation
lack of motivation among senior employees
Advice to Management:
keep working on improving the culture
invest more in mobile

Title: "Keep on yodeling"
Pros: Great place to work. Awesome perks.
Cons: They really need to create value independent from all entities like Alibaba & Yahoo Japan.

Title: "Senior Engineering Manager"
Pros: Good culture and casual workplace. Lots of potential to make a big impact with a large user base.
Cons: Poor technology and many impediments to productivity. Lots of attrition and talent drain.
Advice to Management: Do everything possible to make this an enjoyable place for engineers to work.

Title: "Great people, still face some challenges"

Great people to get along, still have many talented people both old and newly hired;
Great office space and work environment: food, gym, snack, coffee, perks etc etc;
A wide variety of jobs and products to work on, improve and learn;
Still many opportunities to build this oldest internet giant back up; many oppty to move around especially for individual contributors (engineers for example).
Cons: Takes another a few years to go back to meaningful growth. Not a high growth company at this point which limits senior people mobility.

Title: "Software Engineering"
Pros: Fun environment to work in
Cons: Hard to believe in value of Yahoo
Advice to Management: More communication to engineers

Title: "Not so good as it used to be"

- lot of fun events on campus

- few teams are really doing good work
- CEO is putting relentless efforts to revive the company
Cons:
- middle management is clueless
- middle management talks more and deliver less
- quaterly performance rating (QPR) is a farce
- constantly changing leadership also keeps changing product roadmaps and vision and makes individual goals ambiguous
- some stuffs in management is not technically sound and nurture favouritism to get things dine in their way
- team morals are at the rock bottom
- work life balance is at toss
Advice to Management: - please get rid of QPR its being wrongly used and bringing no value

Title: "Fun if a bit frustrating"
Pros: Some great people working there. Great food. Fun atmosphere.
Cons: Overall feeling of being second rate. Everyone uses Google products, even if Yahoo equivalent exists. Yahoo ads often market scams/malware, but nobody I talked to seemed to mind.

Title: "Great Company"
Pros: Great culture, awesome people and fun environment in which to work. There are a lot of opportunities to grow in the company.
Cons: There are no cons to working at a great company like Yahoo. The culture is great and there are a lot of opportunities to be found.
Advice to Management: The management at Yahoo is excellent and they are all great, forward-thinking leaders.

Title: "Frontend Software Engineering"
Pros: Learned a ton as this was my first internship. Taught me all the fundamental concepts needed to work as a front-end engineer in the industry such working with MVC frameworks, writing modular, and more performant code. Amazing manager and some of the best engineers to learn from.
Cons: Can't come up with any.

Title: "Good Company"
Pros: Good work. Great benefits. Free food
Cons: Bad management. Everyone is behind quarterly goal and nobody looks at the long term goals.

Title: "Takes advantage"
Pros: The pay is on the higher end.
Cons: They really take advantage of freelancers. You're working 40 hours a week at least, so really you're not able to have another job -- yet you're denied benefits or treated as well as full time employees.

Title: "Great team"
Pros: I love the team that I worked with. Instead of being reactive to the releases and production issues, I got wonderful support from my management to put resources on improving quality. It is the trust and the long term vision/willingness to invest in the future that gave people the incentive to work harder.
Cons: unfortunately, not every team is like that. while it is a nice to place, you just have to find the right manager that has the vision you agree with.
Advice to Management: The CEO will get a much more accurate picture by just sitting in all kinds of engineers meetings to get a real feel about what stalls engineers.

Title: "Chaotic but cushy"
Pros: Amazing perks, I can understand why people can become complacent here. The people here make the company great. Very positive company culture.
Cons: Not much in the way of innovation, orgs are way too siloed and needs more risk takers. Marissa is also too much of a micro-manager to the extent that we can never get products out the door on time.
Advice to Management: Empower your leaders to take creative risks, trust them.

Title: "Positive"
Pros: High pay good work life balance
Cons: Not as high as google facebook

Title: "Technical Yahoo Service Eng Sr."
Pros: great work environment, great benefits.
Cons: uncertain future in terms of market share, management and competition.
Advice to Management: Keep doing good work.

Title: "Love to Yodel?!"
Pros: Great company and culture, awesome vision and great people. Free food and many free services too, including onsite healthcare. Lots on EV charging stations, even a gym.
Cons: No Real Cons, it's a great place to work

Title: "Great Company for Career Growth"
Pros: Teams are lean and fluid, allowing you to move into your preferred areas. Top performers have good opportunities for advancement. Consider these facts when comparing Yahoo to Google or Facebook. Perks are top notch, work/life balance is fair for the industry.
Cons: Yahoo needs a new market leading product to return it to growth and allow it to stand out from the competition. There are a lot of legacy products that are on life support and may take up some of your work day. Flip side of promotion opportunities is adjusting to frequent re-orgs.
Advice to Management: Focus on emerging markets to get a jump on the competition. Share peer company compensation and promotion cadence to current employees so that they clearly understand the personal advantage to staying with Yahoo and not looking elsewhere.

Title: "Ok"
Pros: Good environment to collaborate and work together
Cons: Could have immersed Hotjobs better
Advice to Management: More attention to new employees

Title: "Frustrating"
Pros: Great benefits and a lot of responsibility.
Cons: Lots of transition with very little stability.

Title: "Yahoo Review"
Pros: Great Benefits. Supportive co workers and management. Free meals. Free phone. Paid gym membership. Ping pong table. Foosball on site
Cons: Not always many opportunities for upward mobility
Advice to Management: Pay your lower level employees more and keep them happy

Title: "Senior management needs a change"
Pros: Free food and beverages. Newer management additions are bringing intelligent ideas and change for the better.
Cons:
Senior management in the location has no clue how to run the support business unit in Hillsboro and continuously makes uneducated decisions. Morale is at an all time low and most of the talent has already left the company seeking new opportunities and career advancement.

When job opening come up they are almost always filled from the external sources since backfilling positions is close to impossible. The hiring process needs to be completely revamped or internal growth will continue to be a scarce commodity.
Advice to Management: Proper management training as well as adding experience to the team would improve life dramatically.

Title: "Tech Yahoo,Sr"
Employee Title: Tech Yahoo Software Dev Engineer Senior
Pros: good place to learn stuff. great food
Cons: poor work life balance ..nothing much
Advice to Management: n/a

Title: "Project Manager"
Pros: The people - some of the coolest and most talented folks in the industry.
Cons: Non-competitive salary and disorganized upper management.

Title: "Sr. Product Manager"
Pros: Good environment. Interesting work. High energy. Lots of interesting products to lead and lots of opportunities.
Cons: Playing catchup with the competition. Does not leverage media properties to their fullest potential.

Title: "Good company to work for in general"
Pros: Fairly good work life balance. Maternity/paternity leave like any other companies. Free-food.
Cons: No so well established reward system. Quarterly performance review
Advice to Management: Value and reward resources appropriately.

Title: "Take the good with the bad"
Pros: Good benefits, good work-life-balance, nice offices, relatively nice people.
Cons:
Huge amount of corporate politics. You will be spending most of your time playing the Yahoo
"Game of Thrones"
Advice to Management: No idea, get rid of politics and make stuff. Too many people managing, not enough people making.

Title: "Good place to work"
Pros: The perks, the people, the atmosphere and work environment. Compensation is good as well. Overall it was an enjoyable experience.
Cons: It is a big company so there is some red tape to deal with, and lots of meetings that can be counter productive.
Advice to Management: I'd recommend a focus on improving the content to improve advertising revenue. Read the comments of news articles, the articles that are pulled in from 3rd parties. Often times the content gets messed up (e.g. missing videos, pictures, etc) which makes the article almost useless.

Title: "Treatment is well"
Pros:
Free food, nice office, open space.
Nice co-workers
Cons: Company future is not very prospecting

Title: "Amazing place to work"

Title: "What is happening (or happened)?"
Pros: Perks like free food, coffee, phone, etc. Flex sched, nice campus and facilities, smart ppl. Clean, bright environment, shuttles, parking, smoothies, mobile services (dental, health, haircuts, etc)
Cons: Direction, career growth, motivation, QPR - quarterly reviews, constantly channging priorities, inexperienced management. I really dislike the time and effort the QPR dance required.
Advice to Management:
I was there for 8+ years.

Overall I had a fulfilling time there, although the ups and downs were trying.
I miss yahoo because of the friends i no longer see, but most of them left anyway.

Biggest con that comes to mind is the qpr process; honestly, it is quarterly and often, and then yearly. And each time it is a week long process.

I see it as short sighted; it measures and quantifies. It separates and it divides. It does what it does, but it does not motivate people. To some, it does the opposite.

Translation - the QPR system at Yahoo tries to identify top performers for possible rewards. It does, and sometimes the right people get rewarded, although engineers are super hard on each other compared to other functions. Why is that?

The QPR system at Yahoo does not motivate employees as a whole. It possibly does the opposite.

Define a singular mission. Teach others. Motivate the employees to perform, then measure their performance, then feed them. Do it in that order.
