Cons: Loss of focus in some areas, slow execution, evaluation and reward process not so effective, engineering instead of product driven.
Advice to Management: Flatten the hierarchy structure, so communication become easier and more effective. Focus more on execution. Give more support to product managers. Have better alignment among different organization units.

Title: "Great people, nice atmosphere, good balance of working hard and having a life."
Pros: Proud of the brand, great group of people, planned out time lines so projects got the attention they needed. nice campus and working environment. Good selection of food in cafeteria.
Cons: Ran into problems with projects with low budgets and lack of internal resources to complete big approved projects.
Advice to Management: Good production in marketing takes money, i'm not saying huge budgets but enough to make it look great or good. I didn't get the feeling it was that high of a priority at Yahoo. I was there pre Marissa, But I'm sure its better now with Marissa. Would've been happy to work for her.

Title: "Great if you're an Engineer or Developer - Otherwise, beware."
Pros: Good benefits, perks, most people are nice.
Cons: Executive team is not aligned. Open and constant bickering leads to a volatile environment. Limited to no communication. Inconsistent direction given be each executive. Limited accountability with mush blame being pushed to lower management. Extremely political with tons of micro-management.
Advice to Management: None. They don't listen.

Title: "Not #1 in industry"
Pros: Benefits might be ok with the health, vacation, stock options. Opportunities are in California.
Cons: Management needs to learn how to manage a team
Advice to Management: get training - appreciate and reward your employees that actually do a good job

Title: "Not for everyone!"
Pros: Great engineers but poor management.
Cons: No flexibility and strict management.

Title: "Amazing"
Pros: The working environment is great, a lot of cooperative and friendly people. It's easily possible to maintain a healthy work/life balance, and there are lots of great amenities at the main campus to help that balance along.
Cons: It isn't always easy to get the resources you need, and priorities are eternally changing.
Advice to Management: Give up the Google-like HR practices, they are elitist and ineffective.

Title: "The payments department will make you work like a slave."
Pros: There are some smart people there and its great to work with smart people.
Cons: Leadership has no idea of work life balance. Make you slog like a slave and then have the gall to say that 'this is not enough dedication'. People work 12 hours easy and apparantly thats not enough. Plus promotions are rare.

Title: "Great company with great people"
Pros: The chance to make a difference in the digital market arena with a fantastic solution.
Cons: There are no cons to working there that I can think of.

Title: "Great company to work for - amazing benefits - very smart people!"
Pros: Lots of freedom to do the things you want and how you want to get them done - no micro managing and each employee has a great amount of accountability.
Cons: Have not found many yet - other than the challenges that come from working for a huge company.
Advice to Management: Make some of the processes a little easier - less red tape.

Title: "Aging Company Trying to Catch Up In Everyway But Not Doing It Well"
Pros:
* Tight knit group of experienced people who actually knows what they're doing if given the chance rather than chasing after strategy of the moment.
* Can you say Alibaba?
Cons:
* The next level of senior management below Marissa is comprised of yes people who are more interested in covering themselves than having the backbone to offer an opposing view which can lead to so much more creativity and innovation.
* Bizarre HR practices and company policies in the name of "creating a company with cream of the crop" staff which are rather time-wasters like the quarterly review, the chokehold on the hiring process, inflexible working schedule and the unspoken insistence and veiled threats on making everyone move up to Sunnyvale or you can kiss any kind of advancement good bye. All morale killers. The latter is really hypocritical as the day-to-day folks are demanded they know how to work in a global environment whereas the Sunnyvale based folks are unable to work effectively with offices located elsewhere.
Advice to Management:
* Might as well get rid of the senior management level if they don't have a say in product output and hiring.
* Have really game changing innovations to compete with the true tech titans of today. When you stack up Y! News Digest, the two online magazines to Google (glass, fiber one, cloud), FB (investment in virtual, cloud), Amazon (web services, cloud), so on and so on, there's no comparison.
Most of the staff is demoralized to the point where it's just a 9 to 5 job for them rather than being excited about working at a company that makes a difference and that cares about its workforce. Everyone is afraid to mention the word "live/work balance" lest they be dinged during the quarterly review process.

Title: "I love Yahoo!, I hope I retire here, I think Marissa rocks"
Pros: Great CEO with actual product experience and the focus to get us in the right place in the market. We've turned the corner with traffic and should be turning the revenue corner in 2014. Bonus is fairly good and they are becoming less stingy with equity.
Cons: No raises if you're higher paid in your cohort. No explanation of who's in your cohort.

Title: "Flawed company with some upsides"
Pros: Generous compensation for many and nice benefits, including free food. There are many competent and driven people who want to get things done.
Cons: Lots of red tape, difficulty dealing with proposals across properties. Company lacks direction and is not as technologically proficient as a tech company should be. The competent and driven people who want to get things done may be outnumbered by those who make getting these things done more difficult than it should be.

Title: "Anonymous"
Pros: Tremendous improvements in Branding! Great Food, perks & opportunities for innovation. Recognition for your hard-work will depend on which group you are in and the leader of that group.
Cons: In some groups there is no work-life balance! Aggressive schedule of the projects stresses out every one and quality of the product is compromised at times, to meet deadlines.
Advice to Management: Keep doing what you are doing but pay close attention to the quality of the products while delivering projects as per aggressive schedule

Title: "Moving in many directions"
Pros:
-Dynamic company with lots of good engineers
-Company offers lots of perks, free food, free coffee, free smart phone.
-Free Shuttle transportation to San Francisco
Cons:
-Lack of focus.
-Out of control Quarterly review process.
-Lack of employee development opportunities.
-Out of date proprietary deployment tool.
Advice to Management: Revisit your quarterly review process.

Title: "nice company"
Pros: lot of oppurtunity to learn.
Cons: Some good talent left because of politics...

Title: "Incredibly Refreshing and Exciting"
Pros:
While on the campus and during my interview I was amazed at the positive energy coming from everyone. There is such a belief here that IT can be done, with IT being whatever it is you are working on.

There is also just moment after moment where you hear the CEO's name, Marissa and the contributions she makes to so many teams and projects. I can't say that i have ever worked some place where the CEO takes such positive actions towards group's projects.
Cons: Can't think of any yet.
Advice to Management: Keep doing what you are doing. You are creating a beacon for the renaissance of Tech Companies in Silicon Valley. You are also showing an amazing dedication to the workforce of Yahoo and that causes me as an employee to want to do more, better and faster!

Title: "clear product north"
Pros: company scale and strategic direction
Cons: pressure on middle management, inconsistent employee assessment narrative

Title: "Network that last a lifetime"
Pros: I really enjoyed working for Yahoo for almost 4 years. My job was to bring in the best possible talent and to make the process as simple as possible for my hiring managers. the staffing team is awesome and they work very hard to produce results quickly. Yahoo is a great place to build long lasting relationships.
Cons: Management should not contact their employees around the clock expecting emails to be answered.
Advice to Management: Make sure your employee has work life balance or they will likely suffer fatigue. I had several great managers when I worked for at Y! Apart of me will always bleed purple!

Title: "Invigorating"
Pros: Highly collaborative atmosphere, swift pace of execution, razor focus on growth, tremendous scale of operations, once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to be involved in the resurgence of an internet pioneer...need I say more?
Cons: Nothing is guaranteed here -- sign up for the mission at your own risk

Title: "Great people, lousy management"
Pros: Many really smart and passionate people
Cons: Lack of direction from management because a lot of middle managers came to just ride the wave then move on to another company
Advice to Management: Figure out what Yahoo! is and empower your talented employees

Title: "good environment"
Pros: a lot of various food friendly people
Cons: low efficiency of human resource

Title: "Rocking co-workers"
Pros: benefits are great along with very relaxed working environment,
Cons: Sometime you meet people who cn be defined as 'burned-out'

Title: "Good place to work, but engineering focus wanders"
Pros: In my experience, most of the people working at Yahoo are level-headed and easy to work with. They are generally good technologists, and implement good solutions where the engineering atmosphere encourages that behavior.
Cons: Management turnover, from the highest level down to the lowest. This undermines morale and also provides for an ever-changing technological focus, which is one of Yahoo's problems.
Advice to Management: Commit to building solid and imaginative technology at the same time. The engineering culture needs to cultivate openness and risk-taking, without the need to copy what is being done outside of Yahoo.

Title: "company has fundamental structural problems that have long gone un-addressed"
Pros: friendly, collaborative work culture. Nice people. Good perks - in line with the best tech companies.
Cons:
Lots of incompetent Sr. level managers. Henrique de Castro and his $100M severance got a lot of media attention, but ineptitude reigns supreme in many functions.
Employee rating system is a farce: it's just a way for managers to pick their 'buddies'/pets and get rid of competent emerging stars that make them feel insecure.
Advice to Management: Get rid of incompetent managers. Rating system helps a chain of bad and insecure managers preserve their positions while the company hemorrhages good employees.

Title: "Really not that great"
Pros: Good benefits and free snacks and drinks in breakrooms.
Cons: This was a company I really had high hopes for and after one year left with a bad taste in my mouth. The job presented during the interview process was not at all what it really was along with not being told we'd be working all holidays including Christmas! Important policies were never discussed or thoroughly understood at any level of management at our location and threats were given to employees before managers even had correct information on policies. Disorganized, very unfair work environment, favoritism that was blinding at our location and downright dishonesty from management down. People in our department were given special projects before even proving they could do the job they were hired for as other solid workers that had been there longer sat and watched in disbelief.
Advice to Management: When your motto is: "we only hire college graduates" make sure you treat them as such and not as disposable "agents" or "tech's" it is very degrading. No other advice is needed since HR does nothing to handle the real issues that have been turned over to them.

Title: "Toxic experience"
Pros: Some of the people I worked with were amazing. The rest were there to take up space and collect a paycheck.
Cons: Terrible place to work. Toxic environment. Total pressure cooker. The harder you work, the more they dump on you. Many employees slide under the radar. Only saving grace was that most of the work horses survived the frequent and MASSIVE layoffs.

Title: "Yahoo"
Pros: The food in the kitchen is free
Cons: The process is all over the place

Title: "yahoo"
Pros: free food, free phone, weekly senior updates, nice campus,
Cons: low salary, low bonus, company firing people, boring projects
Advice to Management: stop firing people

Title: "Old, slow, lazy and not really improving"
Pros: - higher salary than competitors (because they have to)
Cons:
- demotivated culture (though improving since Marissa got there)
- poor talent quality (even the companies they are buying are failed startups, B-level at best - except for Tumblr)
- little vision and structure from executive team
Advice to Management: Focus on revenue, not just trying to get more traffic. Also, get some real leadership, not just Marissa puppets.

Title: "Rudderless company with too many ideas"
Pros: Plenty of opportunity to advance, generally good projects to work on. Decent benefits.
Cons: They could never make up their minds about where to go: About every 6 weeks we'd have to stop what we were doing to make a new deck about what we're doing to justify what we'd been doing to the new management. Frustrating.
Advice to Management: Do your research, pick a direction and go with it. Commit.

Title: "Project Manager"
Pros: Global company with good infrastructure and benefits. Professional but friendly environment. A good mixed of talents
Cons: Leadership has changed often due to layoffs and reorgs. Losing it competitive advantages and trying hard to play catch up game.

Title: "Fun, dynamic, chaotic, stressful, and fun again all rolled into one"
Pros: Smart people, exciting projects, great compensation, and amazing perks comparable to any big tech company
Cons: Extremely aggressive goals that are impossible to meet, no consistent strategy, way too many conflicting priorities and groups to deal with, one acquisition after another which leads to even more confusion in strategy and purpose
Advice to Management: Get leadership that actually can lead, execute to a strategy, and deliver. Instead, we seem to have poor performance and celebrate it.

Title: "yahoo review"
Pros: Nice people to work with at the peer level. Free food and free coffee.
Cons: The company seems to be doing way too much at the same time. Yahoo has a very aggressive management; they seem to be trying to please the investors more than their subscribers.
Advice to Management: Yahoo needs to focus on projects that produce a better return on investment.

Title: "Tough sledding ahead, despite the stock price"
Pros:
o Learn all about how to transform a huge company from the ground up - it's what they need.
o Smart people work there.
o Incredible benefits and good pay.
Cons:
o Horribly political - not sure it's changed much since 2012. It's who you know, and top management likes to "skewer" people.
o Addicted to display advertising as primary source of revenue, and seemingly unwilling to make investments in alternate revenue streams.
o Still about content vs. technology. If you want to gain some chops in tech, not the place to go.
o About 5 years late in mobile.
Advice to Management: Diversify. Take risks. Really, truly go mobile.

Title: "Platform solution at scale"
Pros: The opportunity to work with solution on a large scale internationally in a company that has re-born under the leadership of Marissa Mayer
Cons: Large enterprise means projects move slow

Title: "Yahoo is a great place to work"
Pros:
smart people
interesting work
good reputation
good atmosphere
Upper management is now very open to new ideas
Cons:
mid to lower level management can be weak
Prior to the current CEO direction was confused and opportunities were missed

Title: "Good experience"
Pros: Transparency and working on core technologies
Cons: Not keep up the same space of industry on revenue growth

Title: "Great place to work!"
Pros: Interesting issues, smart people, great culture
Cons: Quarterly review process is onerous and destructive to small teams that are performing at a high level.

Title: "Great company to work for for an engineer!"
Pros: Yahoo uses leading edge technology with a lot of focus on open source exposure, large web scale problems to solve, a bunch of talented good people.
Cons: Prior to Marissa Mayer, the company was stuck in decision paralyis, the executives were unable to decide a strategy and lot of competing products were developed which never saw light of dat.

Title: "Your soul will die"
Pros: Great cafeteria! I met some really great people.
Cons: Working environment is stale. People are afraid to speak-up as they might be layed-off - leadership creates a hunger games environment. Infrastructure does not support growth. Products are from 1998. Sunnyvale makes your soul wither away.
Advice to Management: Start over.

Title: "Great."
Pros: Great environment. Choose your own tool to solve a problem.
Cons: Company as a whole is not doing great.

Title: "Great Overall Experience"
Pros: Very Work Friendly and Goal Oriented
Cons: Before, was not organized at all
Advice to Management: None

Title: "Former Great Company Struggline"
Pros: Great Benefits, Great People, ok atmosphere
Cons: management has been changed so many times and the direction of the company keeps chaning

Title: "bureaucratic, poor middle and low level management"
Pros: improved quality of upper management after new CEO. Good quality is slowly but nevertheless trickling down to middle management. Great engineering talent.
Cons: bureaucratic, poor middle and low level management

Title: "Great people but too corporate"
Pros: Great people who worked hard and were ton of fun. Also had regular happy hours and office parties
Cons: As of 2011, was not at all the typical "silicon valley" culture, it was a cost cutting corporation.
Advice to Management: Marissa is already doing it

Title: "Interesting Place to Work and Learn"
Pros: Worked with very smart people, who had innovative ideas. Also, almost everyone behaved in a very professional way. Truly interesting and fun place to work.
Cons: Changes brought about a different kind of organization.
Advice to Management: Figure out how to make money and still keep Yahoo an interesting, fun place to work.

Title: "Good company"
Pros: A lot of good technologies.
Cons: Company appears to be going through a lot of re-organizations.
Advice to Management: Value the employee more.

Title: "Good company poor upper management"
Pros: great coworkers and engineering staff. The perks were getting better but lack of bonuses.
Cons: upper management didnt know how to manage. There was too many management levels. Lieing and berating of employees from upper management. very poor work environment caused from the upper leadership
Advice to Management: aduit who is actually doing what. Creating needless work so someone can justify their job is counter productive. Teach the upper levels how to interact with with there employees(TK's org)

Title: "Fun, challenging and personally rewarding"
Pros: The sales team and management were dedicated to helping sales professionals develop their skills.
Cons: Management levels kept shifting. Senior leadership issues because the company spend several years trying to re-position and re-identify itself.
Advice to Management: None. They did great with the resources and leverage they had at their disposal.

Title: "OK...not the glamor you think it is..."
Pros: This is a company that seems to be turning a corner, however 2014 will show whether new management's initiatives will be bearing fruit or not. There is definitely an energy on the main work campus which hasn't been there for a long time, and people are generally feeling positive.
Cons: The company tends to operate in silos, so much so that information sharing can be difficult, especially for larger multi-team projects and initiatives. This makes it especially challenging for program managers. There is no consistent way to run projects, which further makes it difficult when dealing cross-group.
Advice to Management: Pick a consistent way of running programs across the company. This will facilitate cross-team collaboration as well as movement within the company.

Title: "Great energy and work, with some increasing overhead"
Pros: Company is constantly working on exciting, innovative projects and engages employees across the company to make meaningful contributions and execute quickly.
Cons: Increase in administrative overhead such as quarterly goal setting/scoring, performance reviews, etc. starts to get exhausting. HR seems really off as a whole, resulting in a lot of missed deadlines for things like hiring decisions, benefits enrollment, delivery of employee reviews, etc.
Advice to Management: Please overhaul the HR org to be as accountable as the rest of the company is expected to be.

Title: "New CEO instills confidence, transparency, and technical changes that make Yahoo a great place to be right now."
Pros: Transparency of CEO and Sr. Mgt. strategy, thought process, and decision making; incentives for those who drive change and revenue; talented and cordial people. The fast-moving culture is back with breakneck speed.
Cons: Company still is a risk to join due to its uncertain future (some thrive in this situation, some do not). There remain some bugs to work through in the corporation as it moves upward.
Advice to Management: Keep it up!

Title: "Be cautious"
Pros: The perks that are given by being employed by Yahoo! are great. There is a lot of opportunity to get great insurance and to get many discounts locally just because you are with the company.
Cons: No work/life balance. Micro-management, dishonest authority, untrustworthy work environment, and heavy office politics. Your actual performance is not what gives an employee value here. It is who you know, or who you can successfully push the spotlight to, that is what will get you advancement.

Title: "Smart people, fun, lots of change always going on"
Pros: Smart people, fun, excellent benefits, interesting work and interesting times. Willingness under Marissa Mayer to fail fast and break some eggs.
Cons: Too much change, all ramifications and interactions among multiple changes not always thought out. But Yahoo needs a lot of change so I guess the alternative is worse?

Title: "Headed in the right direction."
Pros:
Working at Yahoo was incredibly rewarding. Yahoo is an established media company that has pioneered so much of internet culture. Working there was never boring; there was always a new strategy being put in place and new areas of growth to focus on.

Yahoo is a staple of the internet and of internet culture that often does not get the credit it deserves. I learned more during my time at Yahoo than at any other period of my career.
Cons: Frequent changes in senior management/C-level management lead to a lot directional changes. Working in a satellite office was difficult at times because we would hear about changes well after they had been implemented.
Advice to Management: Commit to the changes you want to make and stick to your guns.

Title: "Yahoo in Boston"
Pros: Good People, free food, great benefits.
Cons: office is outdated, not much opportunity for advancement in this office
Advice to Management: Move the office.

Title: "A good place to get experience with working with services dealing with a large scale traffic."
Pros:
All the perks expected in a Silicon Valley internet company of the size.
Diversity of products and expertise within the company.
Cons:
Becoming too much like Google and losing identity as Yahoo!
The performance evaluation process that discourages collaborations.

Title: "A real roller coaster of a ride."
Pros: A huge audience means a huge impact for your work.
Cons: Upper management turnover can leave you with whiplash.
Advice to Management: Let your managers manage, don't force rankings.

Title: "Good place to work"
Pros: Fast-paced, always evolving, great benefits
Cons: Hard to get promoted, fierce competition

Title: "You cannot plan to build a career here.."
Pros: good start, you will feel all is good with the advertizement that is thrown at you during induction
Cons: You will soon realize you that you will not get anywhere, and will be having nil to very little leadership with no direction or vision apart from blindly following directions from executives. who themselves are relying on trial and error. you can not plan a career here.
Advice to Management: value what you have if you really wish to grow, do not pressurize employees with policies thought out of your hat with no or minimum consultation with grass root leadership

Title: "Yahoo review"
Pros: Great Benefits, Flexible Hours, Decent Wages, Rapid changes are happening to try and position Yahoo for growth into the future.
Cons: Internal ranking system can seem unfair to some, changed are almost too fast to keep up with, changes being implemented before they are actually ready to go because employees want to hit their quarterly goals, regardless of potential errors or flaws in new system changes.
Advice to Management: Take more time to develop your new systems, platforms, and page updates, rather than rush everything to production. Also, remove/change the ranking system and reduce red tape on hiring.

Title: "It has been very pleasant, but outgrowing the role and size of company makes movement tough."
Pros:
- Solid Company
- Innovating to catch up within the space
- Work life balance still good (although changing)
- Diverse and intelligent people to work with.
Cons:
- Work life balance beginning to shift toward Google
- High pressure with more reviews and box-checking for every employee
- Very structured, limiting movement outside the org you are currently aligned with
- Rapid changes without support plans provided make for a frustrating environment

Title: "Good now, went through a rough patch"
Pros: lots of area's to work in, work with man smart people
Cons: stack ranking of employees, bucket/quota rating system

Title: "High profile organization"
Pros: There are still some smart established employees who still maintain company ethos of innovation, with hard work and fun
Cons: The culture is becoming more and more regimented - Google-like. Innovation stiffled
Advice to Management: More vision, less micromanagement

Title: "One of the best places to work"
Pros: Great company, good team work. Compensation and perks are good. I have had a free hand implementing and learning.
Cons: The rating system that was recently implemented sucks. Good employees lost jobs due to the forced ranking system.
Advice to Management: Reconsider the ranking system which is bad for yahoo.

Title: "Employee's are treated as more of a number than a person."
Pros: Free food (breakfast and lunch). Iphone. It feels like they try and make up for the fact they aren't paying you enough with some percs.
Cons:
Wage is below average. Exceptions are hard to make a case for. It's all numbers and real decisions seem to be made elsewhere and not on site.

Very poor communication.
Advice to Management: Getting information from one dept. to the rest should be a priority.

Title: "As bad as you've heard, and then some."
Pros: The gym is open all day, the cafeteria food is better than average (and apparently free now) and the coffee is free.
Cons: Engineering is a mess. Officially supported software was super outdated (Apache 1.3? FreeBSD 4.x?), teams frequently duplicated effort, official standards (No more FreeBSD!) conflicted with reality (Work in mail? Write your code on FreeBSD). Want to get a small change pushed out live? Hope you like meetings and overhead. The team I was on was "Agile" which meant we sat through 4 hours a week of sprint-related meetings. I was hired to rebuild an existing system only to find out after I started that I wasn't allowed to change said system because too many people depended on it being exactly the way it was (said system came originally from another company Yahoo acquired in the late 90's - think DHTML and Java applets for scrolling text on the screen and you're in the ballpark). So after two months I had nothing to do other than use the gym and hunt for jobs.
Advice to Management: You should seriously nuke most engineering projects from orbit. This isn't an attempt at sarcasm or humor - you'd have an easier time rebuilding entire teams, products, and organizations from scratch than you will trying to improve things by changing a piece here or there. Think hard about why you're buying up all of the startups that you are - how have <10 person teams managed to come up with technology that blows away anything your product team has come up with in the last decade? It's because they're not carrying around all of your luggage.

Title: "wide breadth of opportunities"
Pros: global, large-scale company offers a wide variety of job opportunities
Cons: over 15 years and still not operating like a mature company; senior management doesn't have the vision to run a global company effectively
Advice to Management: stop stack ranking employees

Title: "Tremendously positive experience with great people working very hard!"
Pros: Great people and energy. The momentum is in a growth cycle.
Cons: With a growth cycle, there are always pitfalls and rough patches. Yahoo is experiencing those rough patches yet proceeding forward.
Advice to Management: You have many great people left and new ones coming in constantly. Pay attention and retain those minds and bodies. You don't want this to become a training ground for talent to pick up and leave.

Title: "Great company that lost direction"
Pros: Great brand, solid customer base and motivated employees
Cons: Lack of direction and poor execution
Advice to Management: Make sure to promote employees who deliver, not the ones who do talking

Title: "Yodel like a Yahoo"
Pros: Yahoo has an innovative and fun, casual environment which attracts creative employees and strong talent. The company events were large and lavish at the time, and tchotchkees were aplenty. Upgrade to Pro Fantasy Football was an appreciated ++
Cons: While I was at Yahoo, it seemed the company as a whole was moving too slow. Yahoo was trying to do too much and be the #1 in every category, and along the way it was losing market share. Processes were time consuming and there seemed to be a lot of red-tape. With the change in CEO came (ultimately) positive changes for Yahoo as a whole.

Title: "Amazing place to work"
Pros: No Micromanaging, Freedom to do what we like.
Cons: Work Life balance slightly impacted.

Title: "Intense since Marissa arrived."
Pros: Lots of great focus on products and product experiences.
Cons: Stack ranking and falling quality of work / life balance.

Title: "fast paced applied research"
Pros: Challenging problems at scale, lot of learning everyday both system and algorithms
Cons: sometimes too fast paced, and mediocre work gets into production

Title: "Not recommended"
Pros: casual dress. free food (although it really comes out of your salary...)
Cons: Dishonest management in the Omaha office. The whole company is so disorganized and the higher ups have no idea how bad it is (or just don't care). They get rid of new employees who work extremely hard and bring fresh perspectives to the company, while virtually all managers and directors who have been there since the declines began are unquestioned. No way the company will return to its "glory days".

Title: "Great company to work for"
Pros: Yahoo offers great benefits and cultures. You get to work with brilliant programmers. This is one of the companies that handles the biggest amount data. Get to experience a lot of new technologies for handling it.
Cons: Once you get to know you job, it can get boring because there are things that just have to get done. But there is a room to be creative and have fun.
Advice to Management: Keep up.

Title: "Worst job I ever had!"
Pros: Free food, cell phone expense
Cons: Worst management in the Omaha office! They treat their employees terribly! They are verbally abusive and they lie. They offer you a severence package when they find out you are looking for a new job so youll leave right away and then they revoke it as soon as you walk out the door! Do not trust this company!!!

Title: "Great Products, Fast Paced Team, Culture Needs Improvement"
Pros:
Yahoo! definitely has it's perks as a company, but make sure to vet the team you'll be working on
-smart people on my team
-fast paced projects with company wide scope
-volleyball courts
Cons: -some folks are just there to pay the mortgage

Title: "Great place to work... as long as you don't have to keep looking over your shoulder"
Pros:
- Absolute best benefits
- Great work-life balance
- Great campus vibe
- Opportunity to learn a lot
- A lot of smart people work here
Cons: - Stack ranking has made it very competitive and it's not enough to just do your job well, you have to outdo your peers which makes things very political
Advice to Management: Innovate, innovate and innovate.

Title: "Nice place to work but changed drastically over past few years"
Pros:
Friendly environments with great perks
Smart people to work with
Agile development process, so it always keeps you on your toes (I personally like that, it may be a cons for others)
Cons: Work environment changed a lot during my last few years as the company was not doing well. So many lay offs led to lot of uncertainly at work place and people losing their productivity.

Title: "Fun place to work"
Pros: Catered lunches; relaxed atmosphere; really friendly coworkers; occasional after-hours poker or whiskey bar
Cons: Sometimes feels like have no say in direction of products; sometimes akin to body shop

Title: "Behind the doors politics"
Pros:
Salary, work flexibility most of the time.

Marissa has been good for Yahoo! I do not agree with people who diss no more work from home policy. Maternity and paternity benefits are just great. Even though many will not get to use these, it shows what is important to company and the culture they want to build.
Cons:
Good new talent is very difficult to attract.

There is a cultural disconnect between Chamapign and the rest of Yahoo. People who have never travelled to HQ don't even know. Older managers try gimmicks to keep their influence because they are aware of their technical shortcomings. Sadly likeability of managers is what is keeping them in place. Fiefdoms!

Managers do not give real feedback face to face because it makes them less likeable. Behind the doors though, they do not shy away from taking others down. I know first hand because I overheard a very interesting conversation through the porous conference room walls. There is a very well defined them Vs management Vs HQ thinking.
Advice to Management: There are some good engineers who can make great contributions if they had more honest and technical managers.

Title: "really good"
Pros: exciting work at yahoo really
Cons: long hours at yahoo really

Title: "Good place to work, but needs some small tweaks."
Pros: Lots of different area of technology to work with. Good benefits.
Cons: The review system needs fixing, seems to be a disconnect between what the CEO says and how mid-level management actually performs reviews.
Advice to Management: Ensure mid-level managers are following the directions that were stated by the CEO.

Title: "Great experience, but depends on the team"
Pros: Yahoo! offers a lot of great perks. Depending on the team you are in, often you will work with many talents. Yahoo! has its ups and downs and it constantly learns from its mistakes. While it is not a perfect company, this also means that you can make a difference to make Yahoo! a better company.
Cons: Just like other companies, you will work with less talented people sometimes. My advice is to coach them and let the management know if that becomes counter-productive.
Advice to Management: Keep the project visions super-clear; only then the team can create a credible product. Have company's missions be the guide for the team to create your product.

Title: "Wonderful company that treats employee well"
Pros: I have been there during the most difficult years of yahoo, but yahoo treats employees pretty well, general packages for employees being laid off etc
Cons: Morale. People cannot focus on their work because all these rumors around yahoo

Title: "Value your employees"
Pros: Good working culture, Training ground, benefits
Cons: Politics, Bureaucracy, sense less managers, pathetic engineers and pm's in APT
Advice to Management: stop promotions sub standard people and recognize real people.

Title: "Instill job environment where cornerstone's based on distrust, pile-on, competition amongst peers & broken model of QPR"
Pros: The comprehensive Medical and Misc. Benefits Package. Also have the chance to work with some very smart, funny, and downright cool co-workers.
Cons:
Absolute Burn-Out: Requirements and mandates keep piling on pre-established role. Constant ReOrgs and sudden meshing of completely separate departments/platforms into one single entity. More work, less resources, longer hours, no pay increase.

99% Employees = frustrated/demoralized...

...while 1% (yes, that 1%) of C-Level Execs, SVP's, VP's and Board Directors are Laughing and Singing all the way to the Bank "Mo' Money, Mo' Money! $$$!"
Advice to Management:
Do away with the Gestapo techniques, it's crumby for morale company-wide; meaning, nix the tracking of every single task/update/meeting/phone call/sale/up-sell/etc. You've created a time-suck unlike anything I've ever experienced before as each worker-bee is now, for all intents and purposes, engaging in an everlasting exercise in redundancy by updating an internal system for something already completed so that some team can check their box off and say, "Yep, it's redundant. And time consuming. But they can be tracked now!"

Also, the incessant, passive-aggressive messaging from emails sent by, example, our newest (*Insert 3-letter Acronym) of Global Ops to all of Yahoo on the Friday prior to Christmas at 10pm EST: "Our employees are our most treasured asset. Your sacrifices do not go unnoticed. But our employees can Always do better, and we will all need to do so throughout 2014, oftentimes with more work and less resources." Focus more on employee satisfaction and their work / life balance to maintain an established set of intelligent, experienced, and happy workers vs. the burn and churn. People leave, no added head-count is addressed or implemented, you push the unaligned work on to another employee who is likely already struggling to keep pace and gasping for air; this behavior is all too commonplace these days and is a real shame. There is no longer a Yahoo culture of yesteryear - there is only pressure to do more with less time / less resources for the same pay. No one enjoys it and it is voiced in many circles. But we cannot openly discuss at this stage unless you'd like your very job on the line.

Title: "Painful."
Pros: The snacks were always good. Very often there would be bottomless laffy taffy.
Cons: Everything else. A bunch of dummies. New CEO every 6 months is kind of funny.
Advice to Management: Bottom of the barrel silicon valley management... it's kind of hopeless.

Title: "Great place to work. Lots of smart people"
Pros: A very focused company on the web, yet has many successful products that truly delights many users everyday. Still one of the most successful companies in the internet space.
Cons: Silos within the company is widespread. Working with remote teams is harder than it should be. Weak presence in many international markets
Advice to Management: Treat your employee well. They are your biggest asset.

Title: "Fun, for a bit"
Pros: cool people, interesting scaling problems, Fun Parties. Still have many friends from there to this day. Its good for a big company.
Cons: Constant treat of layoff. Low pay, benefits were ok. Re-org, re-org, re-org. Too many bosses, not enough workers. Older technology.
Advice to Management: Pare down the management structure.

Title: "Rankings Suck.. even for top performers. Pay sucks."
Pros: The rank and file people are awesome.
Cons: Human Resources and Executive Leadership
Advice to Management: Stop ranking and yanking. It is VERY demoralizing, even for top performers.

Title: "Good company to work for"
Pros: friendly, free coffee, high energy
Cons: lots of changes and reorgs

Title: "could have been better"
Pros: Good Perks and lately morale is good
Cons: Curves can be used to get rid of people
Advice to Management: Clean up management first before you clean up the lower level employees

Title: "Headrd of Review"
Pros: employee friendly, professional work, challenging and satisfactory
Cons: Difficukt to get identified,team syncronisation is a challenge

Title: "Redundant people and roles"
Pros: In CU area Yahoo is one of the better option for software development. All at site enjoy work and $$s.
Cons: Subtle level politics to keep favorite people (read "yes sir/madam") around by shuffling them around to different roles or teams. Good engineers who disagree have been let go using HR designed performance tools. Managers here define their own version of Yahoo way/culture to justify their deplorable actions.
Advice to Management: Finer oversight is needed from VPs. Do not fall for happy, smiley faces.

Title: "Good engineers. Mis-matched managers"
Pros: Great engineers. You get to work with the best talent in CU area.
Cons: Managers and directors are living off of their team's accomplishments. Can not have a decent technical conversation with some of the managers and most directors. Can not justify them to be engineering leaders.
Advice to Management: One has to ask what exactly is the contribution of some of the managers and directors besides "managing people". Hire and promote more managers and directors who have "technical" skills and are not just administrators disguised as engineering "managers/directors". Fire the grandfathered managers and directors.

Title: "Once a great culture, now turning into a concentration camp."
Pros: Free food, that's about it. All the pros are in the past, the pros are leaving in droves.
Cons:
After all the layoffs and people leaving on their own, the core of hard workers are being overworked covering for those who are gone. Since the recent layoffs were done without any consideration for workforce requirements, they simply let people go based on their imbecilic quarterly reviews, now products are virtually falling apart without people to support them.

Smart managers left or are leaving, the one's that are staying are mostly snakes good at politics and have nothing to do with improving company's performance. Just wait till Ali Baba goes public, and see what remaining value is left in this dump.
Advice to Management: Get a life.

Title: "Yahoo is a challenging and fun place to work."
Pros: Great perks, fun atmosphere at the site level. Marissa has brought a lot of good ideas to the table and there is much less bureaucracy holding up product development as a result. The company and it's products are definitely in the best position they have been in for many years.
Cons: QPR (quarterly performance rating) is well intentioned, but flawed. Suggested guidance on the curve is applied rigidly and people that meet all of their goals can be rated below acceptable standards as a result.

Title: "Bug Fixes != Cool Technology"
Pros: Salary, bonus, easy life. Being in Champaign one is not expected to be producing out of the world results. Low expectations that are easily met. Work is okay, good enough to beef up my resume.
Cons:
Work is slow and not that great. Hadoop and Cloud technologies are well advertized but a closer look will tell you that most engineers are fixing bugs.

Pros are the biggest con. I ruined quite a few years of my career working for managers and especially the directors at Champaign site. Managers have no real control over their teams, all is dictated by the Directors. Some other reviews also mention this and is true that these Directors are technically incompetent and use their political influence to keep themselves at the top. Somehow it has worked for quite a few years. The decision makers in HQ do not want to change them to keep a smooth sailing impression. These Directors have ruined quite a few careers by initially hiring people who were not a good fit for the job, but hiring them allowed to meet their hiring quota. Then they fired some of these people on account of poor performance - of course a bad fit will not perform well. So on both occasions Directors come on top, first by meeting their hiring quota and then when the company was looking to trim, they got rid of the same people. Ironically and ridiculously, some of the same people were hired yet again as part of site growth agenda.

There are three distinct groups of Champaign Yahoos. First with the ones that came in bulk from Motorola. They are the older people. They stick together and take care of each other. Some are good. Difficult to break into this group. Second group is in Champaign because their spouses are in the area for employment. These people are the most political ones and will do anything to hang on to their dear jobs. Group three is made up of independent Yahoos who think they can make a career and living in Champaign.
Advice to Management: Some other reviews suggested to fire the directors. Right-on. You do not need them. New technical managers can handle the site well.

Title: "Linkedin: I Would Not Mind Working Here For the Rest of My Life"
Pros:
- Amazing Culture, second to none - the perfect balance of Laidback/Professional Approach that is so hard to hit in Silicon Valley
- No Management/CEO Bubble - Supportive and Friendly Leadership on the Management and Corporate Level
- Make Your Own Way - Almost everyone is given the opportunity to shine, make their own careers, and live their dreams
Cons:
This are minor complaints, really.
- Some teams lack visibility, where attention might be focused on a larger department
- Smaller regional offices do not get as much attention as they should
- Too much focus on product managers, not enough focus on products themselves
Advice to Management: Keep it up

Title: "While it's not without its blemishes, working at Yahoo is pretty good overall."
Pros: The vast majority of people at the company are a combination of personable and very good at their job. The perks are great and the pay is competitive. The company is also more focused than ever compared to recent years.
Cons: While it has improved since Marissa's arrival, there still are a lot of layers of managers.

Title: "Nice place, getting nicer"
Pros:
good management
great colleagues and work.
good work culture
good perks and benefits
good compensation
Cons: bureaucracy still prevalent, though has reduced.

Title: "Great working place"
Pros:
people are passionate and full of energy
good benefits
Cons: the project would changed because of the whole company's structure and personnel changes

Title: "A Decent Place To Work"
Pros: Great people and decent benefits. Good opportunities.
Cons: Company was not in sync with itself or its customers.

Title: "bad form - recruiting team"
Pros: fantastic renovation. They needed energy and engagement, and Marissa really seems to bring it. Awesome products and great opportunity
Cons: I left the Bartz regime. Recently, I was linkedin in-mailed to see if I wanted to come back. I responded that I was happy to talk and the response went to the ether. Seriously? We are ALL busy, but don't email me about an opportunity if you don't have one or can't be bothered to tell me it went away.

Title: "Closest to Google culture"
Pros: Free Food, fun events, iphones, awesome projects and supportive team members
Cons: Cant think of any now
Advice to Management: Keep up the encouragement given to employees

Title: "Constant change, sometimes good and sometimes bad."
Pros: The people, culture and renewed faith in the company.
Cons: There are always cons, depending on the team and department.

Title: "Awesome company to work for"
Pros: Awesome in-office perks such as free meals, coffee bar
Cons: Bachelors degree requirement for most positions ridiculous
Advice to Management: After working in a contract role with Yahoo I was unable to gain permanent employment because although I had an Associates Degree and real world business experience I did not have a Bachelor Degree. Bad Practice considering I was already working in an trained for the role I desired a perm position in. Obviously an image concern with the company.

Title: "Smoking Mirrors."
Pros:
- Free food in cafeterias and kitchens.
- Free music, food and booze around key holidays.
- More free booze every Friday after work.
- Free smartphone and new laptops.
- Free commute bus for certain locations, one even has an employee run bar!
- Many high profile, expensive acquisitions to keep the company in the news.
Cons:
- All those free perks mean less salary when you sign on or no raise.
- Expect to be on-call and working 24/7/365.
- Little to no room for advancement.
- Cumbersome, ineffective quarterly performance reviews.
- Constant negative press is distracting.
- Not sure what all those acquisitions mean for the company.
Advice to Management:
Management should know what to do since they've been at some of the top companies in Silicon Valley, so what I share wouldn't make a difference.

Prospective employees: Read up on Yahoo before you decide to work here because the news stories out there are pretty accurate.

Title: "Bait and Switch"
Pros: The maternity benefit was decent. Benefits and salary paid. Up to sixteen weeks for women and eight weeks for men.
Cons:
I was misled about the position during the recruiting and interview process. The job description was completely inaccurate. Yahoo blatantly lied and lied by omission during the recruitment and interview process.

I was informed the hours of operation were M-F 6am-6pm and that I would have a set schedule. During the recruiting/interview process Yahoo informed me the job would entail lots of detailed analyzing and helping clients to the full extent. I was informed that they would like me to learn some of the technical aspects of the job to start but with my background I will be promoted extremely fast. The recruiter even asked me to stop looking for employment after the interview. She said Yahoo really wanted me to join their team and asked me not to accept any other offers weeks prior to actually extending me the actual offer.

Now fast forward to week 2 of training. My entire training class gets bamboozled with the information that the hours of operation are actually 7 days per week 6am to 9pm and we would be required to work every holiday.

Next, the duties of this position were not Customer Service duties. I was resetting passwords all day. Management focused on how fast and how many calls you were taking rather than the content and quality of the calls. There were no details or analyzing. Not to mention they didn’t want us helping customers to the full extent. Example, one day I had an elderly lady crying to me on the phone because she had a sick family member oversees and she didn’t know how to respond to the email. Management wouldn’t let me help her? I had to tell her to go to the help pages and figure it out herself.

So as time goes by I discussed my concerns with management. I ask about future plans and maybe posting out or being promoted. I'm told, “We’re learning as we grow & we don’t really know what opportunities will be available in the future.” Management clearly developed favorites and placed these favorite employees on special projects. The individuals who spoke up about their concerns were clearly held back and treated unfairly. Management made up the "rules" and policies as they went. To me, this place and especially it's management team are unorganized and extremely unprofessional. You'd be taking a gamble to accept a job as a Customer Service Agent. If you're lucky enough to be one of management's favorites, you might be okay. If not, you will be completely miserable.
Advice to Management: Stop running the department like a telemarketing firm. Learn to be transparent and focus on the customer's experience rather than call volume. Take some ethics courses.

Title: "Pretty good work environment"
Pros: There was a lot of focus on team building which definitely helped day to day activities considering support teams were spread out internationally. I loved working here and the Yahoo! culture. If you live in California and have the opportunity to work for Yahoo! I would recommend it even though my tenure with them was not on the best of terms.
Cons: I didn't want to relocate so my opportunities to changes positions/roles was limited. I ended up being laid-off, as well as, the majority of the rest of my team in New York. The company itself seems to be doing poorly so that may affect other peoples decisions to work for this company.

Title: "All Smoke and Mirrors"
Pros: Free food (but isn't good), good health benefits..
Cons: Terrible 401k first and foremost. For a company of this size, offering 25% on the dollar is miserable! Also, if you care about being a good worker and being recognized for your good work then don't bother working at Yahoo because it will not help you in the long run. Everything is determined by who the Directors and managers like regardless of work ethic or quality. The worst nepotism I have seen to date.
Advice to Management: Get off your high horses. Yahoo is quickly gaining a poor reputation and the nightmare of inner horrors that goes on inside some locations will eventually become transparent. Poor training, office cliques that make others feel left out, and promotions given to anyone other than who management "doesn't like!" A big name company with no real substance to back up their name.

Title: "Used to be a great place to work for"
Pros: You can (could?) make a difference if you pursue some passion and just focus on the user and on your work. Treats engineers well. Stability. A lot of hardware to play with and opportunity to learn.
Cons: CEO cult of personality and politics has taken over. Today there are too many management layers with unclear benefit. Tim Koogle was a top-rate and outstanding CEO: passionate, wise, visionary with second to none people-skills. After him it was all downhill: a hollywood tycoon that cared mostly about the hundreds of millions he took, a foul mouthed lady with no vision, a resume liar, and now a narcissistic, somewhat dictatorial, knows it all type. The best and brightest have left the building. It is hard to get inspiration by looking up.
Advice to Management: Not sure. There's too much mediocrity in top levels, but comparing the two eras, I'd say: bring back the pagers and let those in the trenches push to production again.

Title: "Yahoo has left its best days behind"
Pros:
- New product launches are bootstrapped with millions of users, which is a rare luxury in this space.
- The company still has some good talent remaining, although I am not sure why they are still around unless they are the recipients of RSUs that the CEO has given out to a lucky few.
- Free food. Free shuttles. Company sponsored Mac Air and iPhone with unlimited minutes and data plan.
Cons:
- The company, its products and technology are well past their prime. Their loyal users are aging and the brand is no longer relevant. Company's strategy to get back to relevance is still unclear and performance to date remains spotty.
- Marissa makes every single major product decision in the company - feature, functionality, pixel level design decisions, you name it. Nothing moves without her approval, which can take a while coming while teams burn rubber iterating through multiple options as they try to second guess her constantly shifting preferences.
- The internal work environment is stressful and fast moving in pockets while other teams still churn out buggy code once a quarter. It just depends on where you happen to work and how important your team is to Marissa Mayer
- Career advancement is limited as leadership is being brought (or rather bought) from Google and acquisitions
Advice to Management: Back off a bit and let the teams find their voice and innovate. Stop spreading investment in areas where competition is extremely strong (e.g. search, social, communications, ad platforms, etc) and double down on content/media which has always been Yahoo's strength.

Title: "Good but challenging. Lots to do."
Pros: Challenging work environment. Good opportunities.
Cons: Too goal oriented and performance oriented.

Title: "Exciting time to be at Yahoo"
Pros:
I joined before Marissa took charge so I had the privilege of seeing the change from old Yahoo to new Yahoo.

Perks of old Yahoo: Free medical and dental coverage, casual attire, smart people (but jaded due to poor leadership), buzzing office environment, very competitive pay.

Additional perks after new Yahoo w/Marissa: Free food, free smart phones, strong leadership, smart people (now enthused about the great trajectory and changes that have been thoughtfully and efficiently executed), the leadership sets challenging goals, they are not just sales people they work very hard to fix issues that were previously ignored. It of course takes time, but changes are absolutely happening. It's a great time to be at Yahoo.
Cons:
We do not market. There is a mentality about not bragging and I hate that people love to hate on yahoo because sometimes people love to see an old successful corporate giant fail and this is what happened.

There is practically no PR team. Before I joined Yahoo, I felt the same way as everyone else...it was an old giant trying to stay alive and losing to Google and FB. After joining and after Marissa's complete overhaul of management, I learned we are top rank in a number of categories: Yahoo Sports is #1, Yahoo Finance is #1, Yahoo Mail is #2, Yahoo is #1 in traffic, Yahoo Weather App won "Apple's Design Award" beating out all other apps...these are just a few of the 2013 rankings.

5 years ago, I'd want to work at Google, but you want to be somewhere that's gaining momentum and that's Yahoo. We are an underdog, but we stay hungry and we have a strong leadership now. There is so much to be excited for.
Advice to Management: We have a lot to be proud of. Market more and educate people. Case and point - that negative work from home news that went viral - did you know that only affected a handful of employees who were taking advantage of this by not logging in when they did "WFH". Externally it became big news, internally it was a simple and necessary call out to a small group of slackers. Work life balance is key here and WFH is never an issue for reliable and trustworthy teammates, as is the case with any company.

Title: "It's great working at a company with very smart, motivated individuals"
Pros:
1. The culture is new and approved with Marissa Mayer on Board
2. They push you to think outside the box
3. There's great collaboration, accountability and reward
Cons: Slow to make decisions. Too many layers for approvals

Title: "Great work/life balance"
Pros: Great work life balance and competitive salary. Also very smart people to work along side. Have the ability to move laterally and to other groups.
Cons: Initiatives move slowly. A lot of process that is inherent in large companies.
Advice to Management: Things have been improving, so keep improving morale and product to keep and gain users.

Title: "The Best of Times, the Worst of Times"
Pros: Good blend of big/small, consumer, family-friendly and innovative
Cons: Leadership turmoil and lots of paycheck collectors

Title: "Enjoyed the experience. Still need a lot of process work,."
Pros: The perks are great. Free food and phones. Easy going workplace.
Cons: Not a lot of compliments are thrown around to the ground level employees.
Advice to Management: Start evaluating employees on their merits, rather than in comparison to their peers.

Title: "Excellent"
Pros: Everything is good at this company
Cons: No cons to provide for this company.

Title: "Was exciting creating news on deadline.It w"
Pros: Great colleagues to work with, who are all competent at their jobs. It was great when we could work from home and at the office when needed.
Cons: Their new PD2 content management system was horrible and not ready for prime time. The new mandate to all work in the office was disappointing. Especially considering if you work until midnight each night.
Advice to Management: Consult with editorial before changing content management engineering.

Title: "HAd fun during my internship"
Pros: Free food, shuttles. Lot of Hackathons
Cons: Lot of red Tape among teams to get the work done

Title: "it was good experience i would recommend you to know about the company as much as you can because the interview was toug"
Pros: you get to learn a lot and it is very fun working with very bright young people I would def recommend working for yahoo it is such a great place to work
Cons: some people have really heavy accents from other countries so it is very hard to understand what they are saying, so yeah that is very stressful if you are used to american english
Advice to Management: train better

Title: "experience of yahoo"
Pros: it was good time to work and study there. most guys there are fun and nice.
Cons: up and down , up and down.

Title: "Yahoo is the ever-evolving company!"
Pros: The perks can't be beat! Free food! New phones! New baby policy and 5 yr sabbatical are among some of the best!
Cons: Politics can get in the way of promotions or pay increases. It's more about who you know then how you perform.

Title: "Nice culture, lost a step"
Pros: Great people, nice office, can move up.
Cons: Lost their edge, not enough appetite for change.
Advice to Management: Hire hungry young talent.

Title: "Overall satisfied but company can still have some dark age tendencies."
Pros: Company was in the process of rising from the dead and rebranding itself after many years of unfortunate circumstance and mismanagement. Very cool to see this internally. Has great atmosphere and most teams are pretty cohesive. Though pay is moderate, they take very good care of their employees. Did I mention lunch is free!?
Cons: Still has dinosaur tendencies. Office can feel a bit cramped with the looming sense that you are being fried by fluorescent light. Four quarterly reviews is pretty excessive. Can get lost in the Goliath of an infrastructure. Not too many company outings or team building opportunities; I still felt after a year in the office that I barely knew anyone as most people kept to themselves under tall cubicle walls.

Title: "Great dynamic environment. Lots of creative, motivated minds...loved it!"
Pros: Technology, talent, energy, motivation...the energy was contagious!
Cons: Unfortunately, I came on board a few months earlier and my department was re-org'd out :-(... myself amd VP were hit with the first phase of layoffs.
Advice to Management: Please continue to consider the talent that was hit with the layoffs. Many of us, still bleed purple..we are loya to the product and are proud of having this on our resume.

Title: "Editorial IV"
Pros: Here are the pros of working at Yahoo: Hard working teammates, great benefits/OK salary program, free food, smart tech, inspirational CEO, products improving.
Cons: Bureaucracy gets in the way often. There re many management layers between lower level employees and the top and that can hinder getting things done at start-up level pace.

Title: "low pay but good stability"
Pros: laid back, good benefit, easy going
Cons: low pay, lack of ownership
Advice to Management: promote faster and pay higher

Title: "Very good company to work"
Pros: Work with bright engineers, everybody is respectful
Cons: The time I was working, vision for company was not clear

Title: "Good people, company's going in the right direction- still some red tape to get thru"
Pros:
Good benefits and perks
Opportunity to work hard and learn a lot
People seem to be generally happy- so it's a good environment right now
Cons: Too many changes that happen because one person (CEO) makes a decision, that trickles down and affects too many people. Not enough leadership at the top to challenge the CEO decisions when it comes to people. Understand she should lead product/revenue facing decisions. But when it comes to the people and how the employees are treated, an algorithm or calculation won't work- they are humans, with feelings and desires.
Advice to Management: Get out of the details, and let your leadership team lead. They are paid to make the big, tough decisions, so let them. Quarterly performance reviews, forced distributions, etc just blog down middle managers and add's to the frustration around a lack of empowerment and autonomy.

Title: "Enjoyable place to work"
Pros:
- Lot of existing tools quickly build a product
- Groups are generally fairly autonomous, you can have a say in product direction
- Perks aren't bad
- Plenty of smart people haven't left, can still learn quite a bit
Cons:
- Lots of layoffs (at the time)
- Misallocation of resources- some groups have more people than they need, others don't have enough.
Advice to Management: Free food was a great idea. Huge morale booster.

Title: "Great place to work"
Pros:
*Fun work evironment
*Decent Pay
*Amazing co-workers
Cons: * Sometimes unclear job progression for some positions
Advice to Management: Create clear paths for progression in company

Title: "Wonderful roller coaster ride in the ever changing internet industry"
Pros: Marissa Mayer, Agile Product Management, Global brand with industry leading products, diversity of portolio. Strong culture being built back by Marissa
Cons: Revolving door for management. Many years of no clear direction for company. Competitors seem to win in spaces Yahoo should be leading.

Title: "used to be a good place to work"
Pros:
friendly casual work environment. I enjoyed working with multinational teams.
yahoo have good training system and it helps employee to continue to grow.
Cons: management don't have a clear vision (and stable product) for the future and keep wasting resources.
Advice to Management: the company have too many layers and not easy to brings up good ideas or opinions.

Title: "Great work-life balance"
Pros: Yahoo! is a major brand in the IT landscape and it is a great place to be if you are looking for innovative projects. The culture is fun and casual. Free food, lots of benefits. Hours used to be even more flexible, but it is still a great work-life balance company and it is green. The products you work on are impacting life of billions of users around the world. Love it :)
Cons: Difficult to move up with career. Very much Sunnyvale centric. Can get frustrated by the pace... many projects we work on end up not going on production or getting killed very fast. But that's the IT industry. Lots of work with teams in China and India late at night.

Title: "Amazing turn around of morale by Marissa Mayer"
Pros:
Perks and benefits are one of the best in the Valley
Marissa Mayer's leadership
Smartest and nicest colleagues around
Cons: Some of the previous senior managements are still causing more harm than good
Advice to Management: Listen to your employees!

Title: "Was a difficult place to work 2009-10"
Pros: I was very unhappy, so I cannot say I had any positive experiences. I was placed in an odd team, this could have contributed to it.
Cons: Feudal system feel to the company, the VPs were like dukes and the CEO the Queen. All were unapproachable. The company wasn't doing well and I watched several rounds of layoffs. The commute was long and tedious and the job I had was very unsatisfying. I've moved on from the experience and the culture has probably improved. But when I was there it was a difficult place to work.

Title: "Nice place to work"
Pros: Work Culture, transparency in process and work and Provisions
Cons: Still into old technologies and more support than development.
Advice to Management: Keep the right person in right place

Title: "Great work culture and smart people"
Pros: Provides awesome perks. Good environment overall. Intelligent colleagues to work with. Appreciable employee recognition. Flexibility to change teams internally and work on different projects. Constant encouragement to get better. Yahoo has come a long way from the company that it used to be 2 years ago. Lots of things have changed, for the good :)
Cons: Complications and latencies of a big company. Need to put in long hours to meet aggressive deadlines.
Advice to Management: Keep up the recent good work! There is potential to get better.

Title: "Nice place to work with lot of challenging problems"
Pros:
Marissa Mayer
Great engineering talent
Opportunities to work on challenging problems
Cons: Direction and management vision. Great engineering talent that was not fully utilized to make the company successful. Marissa Mayer definitely improved the situation and leading in right direction.

Title: "Good so far, NCG software engineer"
Pros: Friendly, very transparent culture. Lots of smart people, lots of people to ask for help. All-hands meetings every Friday help build culture and positive attitude. Striving for new and improved everything.
Cons: Lots of management, still stuck in some old ways (kind of a given for a company that's been around so long)

Title: "Great Company"
Pros: Great people, everyone is very friendly
Cons: We are using Agile model but upper management still operate as waterfall

Title: "Things are changing and getting better"
Pros:
More focus on technology.
Culture is improving.
Cons: More politics than before because people are grabbing their share of responsibilities

Title: "Good company to work for"
Pros: Work with some of the greatest minds in the valley
Cons: No opportunity to work remotely which may be limiting for some
Advice to Management: There is a need to invest in the people

Title: "Enjoyed the wild ride!"
Pros: Great culture, lots of fun company events. Great benefits and learning and development classes.
Cons: Finance group had a lot of red tape and very political. Everyone always escalated and escalated without really wanting to solve the issue at hand. The organization was very top heavy so made it difficult to be nimble to get things done as you always required approvals upon approvals.

Title: "Account Manager"
Pros: Great work environment and benefits.
Cons: Little opportunity for internal growth.

Title: "Employed during Yahoo!'s challenging years ... not applicable to Yahoo! today"
Pros: Significant global scale company. Mobile, video, big data, and great consumer experiences
Cons: Historic executive troubles in establishing a lasting corporate strategy

Title: "Yahoo is a great company to work in!"
Pros: makes use of the best technology
Cons: they can work on better org structure

Title: "Amazing, refreshed, and a new energized Yahoo!"
Pros: Sr. Management and Execs make it a point to share goals and objectives so you know where you're working towards. Management encourages YOU to strive for work/life balance. Exciting "startup" type environment --- great people, everyone is incredibly team-oriented/collaborative, helpful and just plain nice. Marissa really has made this an amazing place to work.
Cons: Can't think of any right now.

Title: "New competitive culture contradicts "collaborative" rhetoric"
Pros: Yahoo! is full of extremely smart and dedicated employees. It's a big enough company that you are sure to find some area to work in which you are interested. Yahoo! offers good benefits. It has an informal culture. You are generally allowed to do the right thing. If you're an absolute superstar you'll be well compensated.
Cons:
A new way of evaluating employees has come along which, in my opinion, greatly detracts from the once collaborative culture. On a quarterly basis all employees are stack-ranked against their colleagues in their respective departments. They are then placed in a "bell curve" where each slot in the bell curve *must* be filled. If you are in the bottom of that curve for three quarters in a row, you're fired.

This means that if you work in a high performing group you could wind up toward the bottom of the bell curve even though you do a good job. This creates an incentive not to help coworkers, to avoid hiring superstars, and to generally not wish good things to happen for your colleagues.
Advice to Management: Drop the bell curve. Instead of having a Netflix-like weed-out culture that breeds competitiveness and back stabbing, train managers to spot and deal with low performers. Stop issuing edicts from on high.

Title: "Night and day improvement from one year ago. Still work to do, but great momentum now!"
Pros: Marissa has brought huge, positive changes to the company. The company is operating with a sense of vision and urgency that hasn't been seen since it's very early days. What used to take 18 months to get done is now taking less than six. Having everyone work in the office everyday again instead of seeing random people working from home on any given day and on every Friday has made a big difference. With everyone working together in the office 5 days a week instead of 3-4 days a week the company overall is noticeably more productive now. The free food and free smartphones are great, but by far the best change that has happened since Marissa took over is seeing the company focus back on making user-centric products, instead of developing products primarily to satisfy the demands coming from advertisers. The culture of transparency exhibited at each Friday's all-hands meetings led by Marissa has been a breath of fresh air.
Cons: Despite all of the positive changes we've seen over the past year, there are still way, way too many managers. The company could eliminate 50% of the managers and there would still be too many managers.
Advice to Management: Please consider how we can streamline the org chart so we can all work more efficiently. With all of the employee surveys that we've been asked to participate in recently, I don't think I've heard anyone ask for MORE managers, but that's what we keep getting.

Title: "The good, the bad and the ugly"
Pros: Yahoo was a fun place to work provided you landed in the right business unit. HQ is a beautiful campus with free coffee drinks (often barristas will commit your favorite beverage to memory and start your drink order while you are waiting in line). Many onsite amentieis include subsidized cafeteria food, dry cleaning, oil service, fitness classes, hair cuts, dental visits and of course educational training.
Cons: Unfortunatley, Yahoo was one of the most complicated, politically matrixed organizations you can imagine. There was lots of politicking and in-fighting between business units with many embittered longtime territorial veterans. Be ready for turf wars!
Advice to Management: Employees are smarther than you may think. Work @ home was one of the few remaining incentives to work at Yahoo. Marissa made a big mistake by rescinding this perk. The employee hemorrahge will continue.
