Advice to Management: Step up to the plate and BE MANAGERS!

Title: "blah"
Pros: good people trying to make changes (below the silly executive team)
Cons:
poor board
poor senior leadership
lack of agreement and vision
married to 1999 and the past of email and portal
Advice to Management: play a game you can win and not a game that you want to win but have no chance of winning

Title: "Best Company I've ever worked for"
Pros: Amazing People, Great Perks, and Encouraging Environment
Cons: This isn't really a con but you do have to find your own way
Advice to Management: I think more career training would be good to keep people in their positions longer

Title: "Solution looking for a problem"
Pros: The Technical staff is fantastic
Cons: Watch out for the CEO

Title: "It was not a good experience at all"
Pros: Compensation is OK. Good free coffee. I
Cons: Nobody knows what is going to happen next day. Products are not good. You do not feel proud while working at Yahoo!
Advice to Management: Please Sell this company

Title: "Great place to work"
Pros: You work with great people, office culture was very casual and fun. Overall, it's an amazing company to work for.
Cons: Systems and processes are terribly slow and often down. Need better management - it's hard to respect a manager who does not know what you do day-to-day.

Title: "Great place to work"
Pros: Good workers and great career path
Cons: Some lack of innovation from management

Title: "Amazing"
Pros: Good work, nice work culture and awesome perks
Cons: It has been a good experience

Title: "Some great people in the trenches, less so with VPs and above"
Pros: I've met some of the best people at Yahoo!, many very dedicated , smart, and just good people to be around.
Cons: When I was there, it was unfortunately a very silo'd top-heavy organization that had zero / little accountability. There were lots of political fights amongst different teams due to the matrix organizational structure. I would a vast majority of projects that required cross-team collaboration either failed or was diluted so bad in the end, the resulting product/service ultimately failed the end user.
Advice to Management: Get rid of the matrix organization that causes political wrangling. It kills innovation and drive good people out.

Title: "Great Place to Work"
Pros: Smart People, lots of passion. Great benefits.
Cons: Corporate Issues, Upper Management Turnover,
Advice to Management: Continue to invest in product improvements

Title: "An opportunity full or promise that fell very short"
Pros: A lot of new people brought in to help save a sinking ship. Very positive vibe, but a "feeling" can only carry you so long.
Cons: Too many people leading teams who had no business leading, or this was one of the few places they worked so they had no concept of the real world

Title: "Good place to work, getting better now."
Pros: Good salaries, good food, good benefits, onsite gym, good work life balance, good technologies to learn and work with. Food is free now.
Cons: Lot of people were leaving when I left. To many changes. Be ready to work in different teams and different projects all the time, priorities change very often.

Title: "Things are a lot better since Marissa came onboard. Definitely one of the best places to work at so far."
Pros:
Free food
Free phone
Up to date hardware
New focus on cutting edge
Work hard play hard
Cons: Expected indirectly to check email / be ready for an emergency at any time of the day/week

Title: "It's getting better!"
Pros: After 5 CEO's as in as many years, the outlook here at Yahoo! is looking much brighter since Marissa has come onboard.
Cons: Free food? Free iphones? Free Macs? There isn't a CON I think of. Other than I wished these changes happened sooner (Marissa) before we lost so much good talent.

Title: "Underrated place to work"
Pros:
Finally, a product-oriented CEO who gets it!
Huge opportunity for impact.
Good work/life balance.
Renewed management transparency.
Cons:
SVPs and VPs could be stronger.
Prior issues with accountability
Lack of conviction/patience on new products.
Silicon Valley journalists love to make the company look bad.
Advice to Management: Continue raising the talent bar, and stay out of the way.

Title: "Lots of resources, little focus. The People Magazine of Online Media"
Pros: Yahoo makes a lot of money in Internet media. Great brand, global presence
Cons: The company has no focus and is not a product, technology driven company. Brand experts say the biggest problem with Yahoo is that you can't describe it in 5 or 10 words, let alone any single one word or concept, (like Search, Social Network, Online Auctions, etc..) Therefore the Brand and the expectations related to it, are all over the place. No compelling vision, all things to everyone therefore nothing great to anyone. Behavioral Targeting and data-driven personalization technologies were the most interesting area at Yahoo. The rest of the media properties are average at best.
Advice to Management: Find a focus, ANY focus and a story to tell investors.

Title: "Amazing place and right time to join!!"
Pros: Perks, Work Life Balance and a Uber cool CEO
Cons: Not noticed any so far. Probably havent been here long enough
Advice to Management: No advice as of now!! Awesome job with Flickr!

Title: "great comapny"
Pros: threats its developers as rock stars
Cons: middle management... as mostly everywhere.

Title: "Used to be where greatness goes to die; but maybe Marissa Mayer can change that."
Pros: Yahoo properties are visited by hundreds of millions of people every day. Compensation is good. Freebies abound.
Cons: Yahoo lost almost all of its A players, thanks to managerial incompetence and territorialism. This eventually infected every part of the company. Winning ideas did not just fail to thrive, they were actively hunted down and killed. Marissa Mayer may be changing all that - finally.
Advice to Management: I have no advice other than what Marissa Mayer is doing already. Yahoo needed someone to make tough choices, update the culture and technology, and focus on products again, and that's what she's doing.

Title: "Great in the beginning then downhill..."
Pros: Great environment to work in. Main campus was extremely comfortable. Great flexibility and work-life balance.
Cons: The people used to be the reason to work there. Smart, engaged, excited and passionate. Then everyone got lazy and morale was low...probably around the time Jerry & Dave decided not to sell to MSFT.

Title: "Lots of smart people, friendly people, good work/life balance, but too many middle managers"
Pros: My group is awesome: friendly people, very supportive managers, great work/life balance and fun place to work, great perks (free food, free smart phones & laptop of your choice)
Cons: Too many middle managers who unnecessary complicate and slow down the projects, regular lay-offs which demoralize employees
Advice to Management: The current management is moving in the right direction. Keep it up!

Title: "Bastards laid me off, but I still love them"
Pros: Nice people. Good work environment
Cons: What the hell is up with their leadership? The revolving door holds no optimistic outlook for me. They let good people go just to cut costs. Not good.
Advice to Management: Focus. Become Tech company again. Focus on making the technology that can compete and overtake the googles, twitters and facebooks of the world.

Title: "Great company, lots of incredibly smart people"
Pros: Great industry vantage point and many large scale projects to work on
Cons: Several management changes and mid-level employee jockeying
Advice to Management: Clear out midlevel and focus on building great products

Title: "Still trying find its way"
Pros: It is a great place to work with strong culture irrespective of the location one works in. The people are pretty smart and easy to work with.
Cons: The management direction until the now has not been that great. It remains to be seen what will happen with the new CEO at the helm. Many projects get canned after a lot of investment which is a loss both to the company and its people
Advice to Management: Transparent communication and clear strategy/goals is required to move the company forward.

Title: "Lots of ups and downs"
Pros: Great new management, lots of accountability and things moving. People starting to feel excited to work on things and seeing new products released real fast.
Cons: Still buckling under the dead weight carried over for the past 4-5 years. But management is doing everything it can to fix that.
Advice to Management: Do not affect the work/life balance that the company had maintained so far and creating a cut-throat environment.

Title: "Flexible hours but big turnover"
Pros: Flexible hours, could often work from home, generous benefits.
Cons: Big turnoer every year, low morals, hard to get promotions.

Title: "Financial analyst"
Pros: unbelievable people- loved it over there because of my coworkers.
Cons: we would get beat up in the media, but on the inside, we were a family.
Advice to Management: Listen to those in the trenches

Title: "Massive scale, great culture, smart people but too much red tape which makes it impossible to move fast."
Pros:
Great learning environment.
Opportunities to work on products at a scale that most other companies do not have.
Great work/life balance.
Above average pay package, great benefits ( 401k matchingg )
Cons:
Promotion and hiring inside Yahoo! is now more or less a question of knowing someone, not of being the best at your field. Hopefully, Marissa will address this.
Most work is maintenance while developers and engineers wait for the next round of management changes, starting something new is guaranteed to being shut down as soon as the next reorg happens.
Politicking, backstabbing, no directorial and above direction, constant goalpost changing, cronyism.

Title: "No complaints..."
Pros: Good people to work with. Scale if you are an engineer. Huge learning experience.
Cons: Stock not moving up. Direction not clear.
Advice to Management: Board change?

Title: "Great place to learn and get rewarded for results"
Pros:
Great place to learn: companies with this kind of scale can be counted on one hand.
High-performers are rewarded extremely well for the results they produce.
Marissa is changing the culture is so many positive ways.
Cons: The mistakes of the past are still being paid for. (That being said, Marissa is doing all the right things to fix that.)
Advice to Management: The recent changes are in the right direction, and the rapid pace of change is good to see. Keep it up!

Title: "Decent"
Pros:
- Good place to work
- Free food!
- Free phones
- Great learning experience
Cons:
- Difficult to break the mould and do what you want always
- Its still evolving from the recent layoffs. Eventually, I hope it comes up stronger.

Title: "Overall good company, good benefits, room for improvement."
Pros: Being part of such a large scale, global company -- with such well-known media properties -- is rewarding and great experience to have.
Cons: Still a lot of bureaucracy to deal with, and some cross-departmental challenges.

Title: "They have fallen ... and they can't get up."
Pros: Free coffee, above average salaries. Sunnyvale office has great amenities, from gym to (now) free food at URLs.
Cons:
Politicking, backstabbing, no directorial and above direction, constant goalpost changing, cronyism.

Promotion and hiring inside Yahoo! is now more or less a question of knowing someone, not of being the best at your field. Most work is maintenance while developers and engineers wait for the next round of management changes, starting something new is guaranteed to being shut down as soon as the next reorg happens.
Advice to Management: Stop hiring your buddies to quickly bleed the company and start hiring qualified managers, directors, and above. Quit re-orging every three months, with so little time until everything changes again no one wants to start something new. Cut costs by not hiring your buddies into VP positions instead of cutting money for technology and infrastructure.

Title: "Everyone gets laid off eventually at Yahoo!"
Pros: Great working environment. Good Perks. Awesome Salary.
Cons: Rotating upper Management (CEO), they don't know what they want to be. New management always lays off 3000 people no matter who they are.

Title: "What a mess! Can you say YA-WHAT???"
Pros: Great working environment in terms of comfort and perks. Most people are friendly and work diligently.
Cons: No direction and culture is undefined. Turnover is ridiculously high especially at the top. How can you expect employees to be focused when the company has no direction. Management in the department where I worked led through intimidation, dishonesty and fear.
Advice to Management: Keep an open mind when hiring. Marissa is saying degree only - would she not hire a Bill Gates or Steve Jobs? This practice is discriminatory and she should be very careful with this practice. Must lead, not demand and intimidate.

Title: "Invaluable experiences for young employees"
Pros:
Great learning environment.
Opportunities to work on products at a scale that most other companies do not have.
Great work/life balance.
Cons: Politics of a large company means it takes a long time to get things done.

Title: "Love working here."
Pros: Love the culture and the people who works here.
Cons: Kept changing CEOs so there is a lot of changes.

Title: "long-time employee"
Pros: family friendly, recognized and respected brand name for users and as an employer, lots of opportunity
Cons: big boat that is trying to turn around, nice culture is a detriment, still a lot of fat
Advice to Management: decide on a strategy and STICK with it. communicate openly and broadly, and not just downward. empower the ranks who know what is going on, instead of hoarding the plans at the VP level

Title: "Employee friendly company"
Pros: good culture, people are good. company is good.
Cons: management is poor, disjoint. and burbank is not place to be in
Advice to Management: find better fit people in management

Title: "Great company, bad compensation"
Pros: Good culture, good opportunity for growth.
Cons: Bad mgmt, not so great compensation
Advice to Management: Increase the compensation to retain talent

Title: "Work harder and get recognized"
Pros:
There are not many other company where you can experience scale this big. Everything you touch is global and has instant influence toward the world.
Perks & benefits are attractive, including recently started food.
Cons:
Despite recent effort from the company, some good talents left looking for more exciting start ups or competitors.
Initial starting position often determines how far you can go in terms of salary if you stay as individual contributor.
Advice to Management: More transparency will encourage employees

Title: "Good company"
Pros: Competitive pay and great benefits
Cons: lots of bureaucracy and sometimes difficult to get things done

Title: "Advertising solutions is stuck in 1999"
Pros: Yahoo has everything it needs, audience, smart talent, brand recognition
Cons: Yahoo cannot monetize it's visitors because the advertising solutions have failed to innovate. The failure is because of the managements lack of direction which is taken advantage of by sales force by manipulating the middle management in the engineering groups.
Advice to Management: Cleanup sales and Advertising Solutions middle management.

Title: "Balanced Work life"
Pros: Very nice environment to work for. Nice Gym facilities. Free food.
Cons: Middle leaders need to take more innovative ideas.

Title: "Great exposure and opportunity for professional growth"
Pros:
* Incredibly supportive management
* High-level exposure with a lot of responsibility
* Innovative and fast moving environment
Cons:
* Sometimes difficult to navigate through org efficiently
* Bureaucracy can get in the way, but is changing
Advice to Management: Really look forward to Marissa's strategy!

Title: "Loved my time at Yahoo."
Pros: Wonderful group of people to work with and it was an exciting time to be with a fast-growing and dynamic company. I wish them well.
Cons: My job required a great deal of travel which grew to be a bit much after a few years. Still, I had a great boss and a wonderful time working at Yahoo.

Title: "Good company w/ great benefits"
Pros: Good culture, Lot of freebies, Good technology, great perks, laid back work environment.
Cons: Unstable Management, A lot of bureaucracy that hinders your work, Some Sr IC like Chief Architect etc treat others very low and think they know the best.
Advice to Management: Get rid of some bad middle managers

Title: "Great place to work with too much politics"
Pros: Awesome place to work dealing with scale, and a fun culture.
Cons: lots of politics and nepotism, the focal process and hacks are is rigged to promote the favorites.
Advice to Management: Clean house, get rid of the dead weight and let Marissa do her thing

Title: "Solid place to grow a career."
Pros: The people are wonderful. The brand is very strong (everywhere but Silicon Valley) and there is a lot to work with. Also the work environment is really a lot of fun. People do work hard, but they also play hard. The facilities are nice. Great gym, free food, pretty flexible work environment. You'll develop a killer network of people who get jobs all over the tech world, and you'll have a great company on your resume.
Cons: Yahoo! has been plagued with dysfunction and confusion at the management levels. This is a fact, but it's not a showstopper. If you are a leader, you are needed here. And if you are OK with some drama, then hang in for the ride. But it does get frustrating. You have to ignore the press, they are brutal against Yahoo!
Advice to Management: Hire real leaders who can inspire people and move through the confusion. We need people with tech-cred and influential skills who can help keep the talent inside the company.

Title: "culture of consensus, not culture of innovation"
Pros:
- some very nice people
- flexible work hours
Cons:
- entrenched culture of consensus that impedes innovation
- decision-making is slow as molasses
- risk-averse employees
- composition of employees who just want a cush job is growing

Title: "Great tech, terrible product leadership"
Pros: Yahoo has amazing technology and a lot of expertise. I learned a lot working at Yahoo from other really smart people. it's hard to find work at Yahoo scale in other places so this is one of the few companies you can really learn how to scale technology or teams.
Cons: When I worked there a lot people had great product ideas that never made it into products. Rather than innovating or taking risks mostly the product managers seemed to want to copy companies that were taking risks.
Advice to Management: Yahoo needs to start letting the talented people it has contributed meaningfully to the products and innovate instead of letting middle management be conservative all the time because they fear doing something that didn't work.

Title: "It was great while it was great"
Pros: The people are fantastic at Yahoo!
Cons: Senior management is not cohesive in it's approach. Morale has suffered enormously over the last few years and products seem to languish before they're killed off.
Advice to Management: Bring back the yodel. Have a consistent message to the troops and execute on what you say you're going to.

Title: "Hard working, talented people failed by management"
Pros: free food, good benefits, decent pay
Cons:
Senior managers have completely ruined this place
Lots of unmotivated, undervalued, overworked people
Constant fear of layoffs
Low morale - especially in marketing organization
Advice to Management:
Get rid of managers who don't fit the culture and don't respect work/life balance
Make telecommuting easier
Focus on career development for employees

Title: "Depends on the team you get into"
Pros: Free food, good work life balance, good benefits and compensation
Cons: Difficult to change teams. Some teams have pathetic infrastructure setup to work on and test in production with very old legacy code. You get stuck in such a team, it'll be difficult to change to a better team.
Advice to Management: When assigning NCGs to teams ask for their interest and match their skills before assigning them to random teams.

Title: "New CEO, New Attitude"
Pros: Very smart group of people to work with. One of the world's largest user bases with huge product potential. Incredible new CEO with the vision to bring Y! back to life.
Cons: Past failures (CEOs) still haunt Yahoo!... but Marissa is making fast work of retrofitting the company for the future. It will take time to turnaround.
Advice to Management: Get rid of any execs who've been around for a while but haven't delivered. Rebuild trust with the team through transparency and communication.

Title: "They buy companies and proceed to run them into the ground..."
Pros: Pretty good benefits. The company has a bunch of good products and content to offer.
Cons:
If you are not in Sunnyvale, you are not treated very well.
Don't get bought by Yahoo! If you do, you probably won't have a job in 2 years.
Advice to Management: You need to talk to each other.

Title: "Good working culture, collaborative"
Pros: Smart colleagues, good working environment. Despite all the external drama, we kept our heads down and focused on shipping products. Free coffee was a bonus.
Cons: Senior management decision making left a lot to be desired. Kept changing direction. Lacked a will to win.

Title: "Culture and people are great in Yahoo!"
Pros:
Yahoo has some great and smart people in the company. The culture is also great, and the company has a lot of perks.

Since the new CEO, the company looks very promising.
Cons:
Note, my comments are pre-Mayer times. I feel that it is a very self-serve model. It is your responsibility to advance your career. It is your responsibility to file a patent.

Also, I feel that there is too much in-house technology. This is fine, if you provide sufficient engineer resource. Otherwise, I believe this company needs to use more open-source.

Direction of the company is always changing, which is due to the many management changes. We finally find a consistent direction with the new CEO.

Title: "A great company that has fallen down"
Pros: Great brand and technology, with great benefits
Cons: Poor business model and very political management.

Title: "A mixed bad: Great people, Lousy management"
Pros:
- Great people to work with
- At the cutting edge of technology
- Nice culture
Cons:
- Terrible, highly political, overblown management
- No long term vision for the company. The only emphasis is to survive the next quarter
- Too many product managers
Advice to Management: - Leave. Refocus.

Title: "QA Engineer or Technical Yahoo!"
Pros: Working culture and environment is good at Yahoo!
Cons: Work is not recognized by management.

Title: "Great place!"
Pros: Great environment and perks with great people. Great connections for an internship.
Cons: None everything was great about the company as you work at your own pace
Advice to Management: Great People

Title: "about yahoo"
Pros: decent benefit, including generous 401K match, health insurance, ESPP plan, less pressure, relaxing working culture, several competitive services such as news, mail, sports
Cons: too frequent CEO change, not stable, yearly layoff, not clear direction and strategy, no strong growth in business, good engineers leaving

Title: "Lots of opportunities at Yahoo!"
Pros: Great benefits, competitive salary, lots of support.
Cons: No restaurants near the Sunnyvale campus
Advice to Management: More parking!

Title: "Driven by politics ...."
Pros: Many nice people, they try to make employees happy with events and nice cafeteria. Some latitude to contribute and work independently.
Cons: Lots of managers who got there by playing games rather than on merit. Fat management. Product roadmaps were silo'd and people didn't work together or help each other. Very disorganized.
Advice to Management: Get rid of half your managers. Clean up your neglected products like Mail. It's degraded.

Title: "Trying To Innovate, But Too Many Legacy Yahoos Get In The Way"
Pros: Friendly coworkers and some really smart people trying to make a difference. Relaxed atmosphere, good work life balance.
Cons: Too many legacy Yahoos in middle management who block positive change. Culture of wait until a problem is escalated and out of control rather than working on prevention. Bad decisions based on favoritism.
Advice to Management: Cut out a level of management and you'll remove a large chunk of the roadblocks that get in the way.

Title: "Better than you would expect"
Pros: Smart people, good benefits, interesting work
Cons: Bad publicity, lack of coolness factor
Advice to Management: Keep a CEO for longer than a couple of months!

Title: "overly bureaucratic and very top heavy org"
Pros:
smart technologists and product people still abound
new google ceo in 2012 may change culture
Cons:
too many executives and no singular focus
too many touch points to get anything done
Advice to Management: less upper management

Title: "Yodel all the way"
Pros: amazing work culture, friendly environment
Cons:
high attrition rate
inconsistent company strategy and roadmap
Advice to Management: retain what you can

Title: "A lot of talented smart people but, sadly, no vision for the company at the senior levels."
Pros:
Great people
Competitive salaries + benefits
Yahoo! has a lot of great products - it's a shame that there isn't a tighter/closer integration between them
Cons:
Too many silos to work through
You spend more time in meetings than doing actual work (work frequently spills into evenings)
Lack of a consolidated vision for the company
Most people work hard, some are hiding in the gaps

Title: "Great work culture"
Pros: Great Perks, large number of smart people
Cons: Poor management and no definite set of goals or directions

Title: "Great technology, rudderless leadersip"
Pros:
You will work with some very smart and bright people.
Yahoo! experience especially on Hadoop, Pig etc is always a plus.
Cons: Leadership is generally direction less.

Title: "Company of endless reorgs, lay offs and CEOs"
Pros:
- Good Health Plan
- Free Lattes at least
- You learn scaleability by serving one of the most crowded user base after Google and Facebook
Cons:
If you work in Yahoo, you should have nerves to handle never ending reorganizations,lay offs and CEO searches ever since 2008. Since then massive reorgs took place every other year: 2008,2010 and 2012, along with countless smaller scale reorgs went unnoticed by media.
After every reorgs and thousands laid off, then yahoo start hiring agressivelly just after couple of months to fill very same racks, so then quickly Yahoo ends up same headcount before reorg started.

Note for the Immigrants: If you are an immigrant,the outlook is even worse: Yahoo cannot apply for green cards since it's constantly laying off people. Even though you were lucky to get your labor application while things are quite,your application will be denied as soon as Yahoo does a new reorg, which always does!

CEOs and upper management have no clue about reorg,so they hire Boston Consultancy Group to tell them what to do. Do you imagine any of a hot internet companies like Facebook, Apple or Google ever go and ask management consultancies what to do?

Yahoo has simple answer to most difficult problems: ship it to India! If product X,Y,Z (fill in the blanks shopping,travel,messenger,search,advertising) cannot compete with Google,FB et al,always solution is to ship those products to India,expect the amazing talent of India thrive those products. Google,Apple and Facebook must be stupid not do it this way!

From compensation wise,RSUs and stock options are like joke, even principal engineers given RSUs worth of peanuts. Most engineers esp those joined pre 2010 have options drowned way under the water.

Paid lunch
Advice to Management: Stability,focus,please don't change plans every other day. Have a vision for god sake and stick with it.

Title: "Amazing culture, smart fun sales teams but low employee morale"
Pros:
culture
fun
smart sales reps
fun team outings
great on-going training opportunities
good sales materials
great research and analytics available
Cons:
Account Managers are overworked with too many accounts - Many AM's are both AC & AM
Too many company re-orgs with so many changes at upper level mgmt level
need to improve systems
Advice to Management: pick a direction and stick to it. Keep open communication with sales team

Title: "nice company to work for"
Pros:
great pay , great perks (onsite gym, onsite oil change, onsite massage .... these things can be invaluable: for example, with the gym you don't need to spend extra 30minutes driving to and from the gym everyday, so that prompts you to go to gym more, which promotes your health and overall happiness)

great technology (after 15 years of accumulation, it's got many secrets that outsiders don't know, what we had was already the best after trial and error). great people (at least before the large-scale attrition in recent years) so that you can learn a lot from them: to name a few: php inventor; the perl camel book author Randal Shwaltz;....
Cons: some important strategic initiatives not pushing through. yes they are delivered, but the effects are not as great as wanted, so that they did not manage to turn the tide for the company's fate.
Advice to Management: unfortunately the tech industry needs more hype and buzz these days to consider you to be a hot player in the market, though yahoo is having good money flow, it's being ridiculed for not having as much hype as FB, for example

Title: "got great technology but not knowing how to use it"
Pros:
Fun chill culture, great products, huge audience and great technology.
Lots of opportunities to interact with users and industry peers.
Clear career development paths.
Good benefit.
Cons: Yahoo! started as a technology company and created a lot of great technologies that are the bests in the industry and got adopted by many other peers, however, leadership team does not know how to leverage these great technologies and pursuit media path ...
Advice to Management: Go back to technology route and keep innovating.

Title: "Love working here"
Pros:
Lots of smart colleagues to learn from
Wonderful laid back environment
Flexible Hours
Well rewarded for good performance
Foosball and pool tables
tasty cafetaria
Cons:
Comparatively underpaid
Dirty politics in some teams
Too much process
A little behind in adapting cutting edge analytics
Should provide a little training for engineers moving into data analysis
Advice to Management:
Increase the pay to avoid people jumping ships
Crush politics and people going behind the backs of colleagues

Title: "Its a fun environment everybody is really nice and care for each other"
Pros: Great Salary, Awesome work environment, and kick ass benefits.
Cons: Maybe some drainage of talent but we are ramping up and will be competitive very soon.
Advice to Management: Lets keep hiring great Talent into the company at any cost.

Title: "Yahoo WAS a great company to work for... and THEN..."
Pros: As long as things are moving smoothly your schedule is fairly loose and you are free to come and go as you like. The people I worked with were all in the same boat and always were supportive and eager to work with each other
Cons: With the financial situation they are in it seems they are simply not interested in investing in good talent. Also they went from having their fingers in too many pies to having their finger in just one pie hoping it would work but with no real back up for if/when it fails.

Title: "Yahoo! Has taught me so much and excelled my career and knowledge."
Pros: The people at Yahoo! are great! the culture is fun, but hard working.
Cons: The company is pretty unstable, but I hope that it does pick up.
Advice to Management: I hope you can figure out process and stick to a decision that will really grow the company.

Title: "Too many changes at the top in the last 5 years, but still got life."
Pros: Despite the attrition, the engineers there are smart and passionate. You have the opportunity to learn to solve scalability problems that few companies have to deal with. The recent instability has created career opportunities for those who aggressively seek it.
Cons: The revolving door at the executive level in the last 5 years have made it impossible to execute on any strategic plans, because every new CEO or C-Level executive will reorg and disrupt everything that was in motion.
Advice to Management: Stop the executive shuffle. No single executive, organizational makeup, or development methodology is the magic bullet to solving Yahoo's problems. Let people iterate on product experiences to make them better incrementally instead of trying to do some huge change every year.

Title: "Great place to work if you can deal with turmoil"
Pros:
- Great colleagues, environment
 - Pay and benefits are top notch
 - A ton of interesting challenges and people who want to tackle them
Cons: - Frequent turmoil at the executive level which eventually bleeds down into uncertainty and change at all levels

Title: "Not a good place to be anymore"
Pros: Work life balance, friendly environment, above average compensation
Cons: Management sucks. Most of the good engineers are already gone.
Advice to Management: Quit playing re-org game. It is not cool.

Title: "Good Company"
Pros: Good company for you to learn a lot of cool and new technologies. Interesting problems to solve and good people to work with makes it very enjoyable.
Cons: The constant churn in management and reorganizations impacts morale quite a bit and this causes a lot of good people to leave the company.

Title: "Nice Place to work if you keep your head down"
Pros:
Great Benefits and culture.

Pro for some people: this is one company that you can get rewarded and promoted for failed projects.
Cons:
Poor Management - investing in products that have no ROI or revenue gain - lack of directions for the teams. Decisions tend to be made more for personal gains than what is best for the company.

Too many academics and few think out of the box or care about the business of making money. Lot's of inventions and ideas but no ROI. It's sad to say this.... a billion dollar company that don't know how to develop software. Lot's of talk about technology but none on monetize them.

Lots of failed projects - a failed project is one that does not work better than the previous versions, no addition ROI, users don't like it, and is not stable.
Advice to Management: Why? They don't listen or understand. Need smarter and more brave management.

Advice to Management: Treat you people better...Then Sell!!!!!

Title: "Fast paced, always changing work environment"
Pros: No two days are alike in this fast-paced work environment. Work is diverse and challenging with a global audience and impact. Intelligent and articulate colleagues with managers who really do take a personal interest in your career. Yahoo! is a major player despite its critics.
Cons: Critics and negative media are the norm for this major player. Project teams vie for limited engineering resources. Layoffs are always just around the corner.
Advice to Management: Better prioritize around the core user experience, innovate, and iterate. Increase salary levels.

Title: "Don't know where this company is headed"
Pros: Nice people to work with. Also work is at a huge scale. Get exposed to many different cutting edge technologies.
Cons: Bad management. It's been utter chaos in recent weeks. In the recent layoffs they laid off newly hired people.

Title: "Difficult turn around situation"
Pros:
- company tries hard to keep key employees via generous retention packages
- travel to remote offices is encouraged
- opportunity to move up management chain due to high attrition
- pay seems to be above average
Cons:
- a lot of politics
- no vision, lack of direction, slow decision making
- takes too long to kill bad / obsolete products
- a lot of attrition recently - many smart employees left to join Google, Facebook, Microsoft, LinkedIn, etc.
- senior management musical chair / frequent change in direction / frequent reorgs
Advice to Management:
- focus on few bets - don't try to do everything under the sun
- stop frequent transition - moving projects from one development center to another adds very little value

Title: "Unstable"
Pros: Very high profile and lots of unique visitors per month means every move you make can have a huge impact; lots of untapped potential at the company; Santa Monica office is a great location if you move to the area
Cons: Company is very unstable; constant musical chairs in leadership and a lack of direction; lots of talent that is underutilized; no firm grasp of long-term goals as the company at least on the media side of the business focuses only on short-term gains.
Advice to Management: I would recommend fundamentally restructuring the company, reducing the number of independent units, VP fiefdoms and layers of management; focusing on core businesses and offering substantive career opportunities to staff so that talented people don't feel that they have to leave the company to move ahead and so that there is incentive for people to try hard to succeed; also management should focus on long-term as well as short-term goals - and using the media unit to build its brand; career rewards and VP success should not be solely dependent on how much money is brought in each quarter by each unit without looking at how the company is building itself up for the future and building its brand; talented staff is under-utilized and new ideas should be encouraged (whether or not they can be immediately monetized).

Title: "Really high Highs.....really low Lows"
Pros: This is a pretty open environment to work in. I'm sure it heavily depends on the manager and team you work for, but from the few roles that I have held here, I'm free to work where I need to and with the flexibility where I don't feel sufficated. The perks are pretty nice, the expresso bars are a nice touch, but the transportation benefits are awesome! When things are good, this is an awesome place to work for
Cons: When things are bad, it's like walking around a funeral. It sucks being such a public company that is always under scrutiny by everyone waiting to break a news story. Aside from the some times bad press, there are some management issue. There seems to be a lack of leadership, which trickles down the ranks. Constant reorgs and project reassignments can get frustrating and demoralizing after awhile.
Advice to Management: Figure out what the hell you need to do. Get comprehensive input, make a decision. There are a lot of cases of incapable or inappropriate people in the wrong roles.

Title: "Decent place to learn, but people are averse to accountability"
Pros: Yahoo has one of the best set of internal tools to help a developer and they should think about making these open source. There aren't many other companies out there that handle the amount of data that Yahoo does, and no one else has been doing it for longer than Yahoo. So if you are interested in Big Data this is one of the best places to work for the sheer scale at which they operate.
Cons: The attrition rate is unbelievably high, the musical chairs that is the CEO's office is not helping matters. Senior management gets rewarded more for playing politics than for delivering new products/services. The technical leaders want to always play the safe game and just do enough to keep their jobs safe. Multiple teams are always working on similar projects even after the huge layoffs. Teams are very insecure about other teams stepping on their toes and there is not enough collaboration or communication between teams that are in different locations.
Advice to Management: Make some strong decisions that will allow the company to be more nimble. Allow developers to work on their own projects but instill the in them the attitude of Fail fast as opposed to working on a project for over a year before realizing that the project is futile.

Advice to Management: No advices.

The employee ranking/scoring system sucks. Working from home is frowned upon. Too US-centric/forgets is has an international business
Advice to Management: decentralise hiring and product decisions, invest in the international markets, ditch the scoring system for employees, make results the kpi not hours in the office or location

This could help to prevent the middle level manager not doing any works or treat their team member unfairly.

1.not much career progress in search editor's role.
2.not easy to apply for the internal transfer or relocate to other offices. not sure is this just the policy in Taiwan office. but in general, internal transfer is not encouraged in Taiwan office.
3.need to fill in a form on the system which recorded what you have done every hour. Feel like being tracked all the time. This is a valuable job which provide the critical insight. you shouldn't treat people in this role like a supply chain worker.
Advice to Management: promote those people who contribute the most and have the good performance. not always just promote the one who stay in the company the longest.

Title: "Customer care ran as an american High school"
Pros:
very good benefits
nice free food
Cons:
Yahoo! could be a great company to work for if it wasn’t ran like an American High school.
If you have ever seen an American High school movie, with cheer leaders, Football players, nerds, geeks etc.. Then you can get an idea of the environment.
The customer care department in Dublin is ran by a very BAD MANAGEMENT. I am not referring to the team leaders, who probably are as much slaves as the single specialists (better paid slaves, that is), but senior management. The only transparent thing in Yahoo is the effort senior management put into launching their “favourite” employees forward. They’re also very rude as they can’t be bothered to say goodbye to the frustrated “what’s their face” employees leaving the company but they find the time when their favourite ones “finally” get promoted to other departments. Call me naive but a company whose value is “transparency” should make more than an effort to hire better and more humble management.
Customer care specialists are treated as children, we were told what to do, how to do it, if we could laugh or not, what kind of jokes we could make, and if we were good enough we were given treats (like dogs).
Like it’s shown in any American high school movie the cool guys are always under the spotlight whereas the multitude of nerds, geeks and parias are deliberately left in the shadow, no matter how hard they work. HARD WORK IS NOT RECOGNIZED IN YAHOO! (At least not in the Dublin site and definitely not in customer care).
Salaries are low and not balanced to the average salaries for similar positions. Yahoo! management likes to brag we work for one of the biggest internet industries but they pay much less the direct competitors are paying their employees (for the same role). Within the team, employees with identical role have different salaries (depending on “experience”) and this cause uneasiness and bad feelings.
Customer care employees have been hired with the promise of email work only, b to b, but after signing the contract they were advised of some “small changes”: there would have been phone and it would have been a c to c support. And if you don’t like it there’s the door, paraphrasing what I was told when I complained about it.
You may think “oh well, I will stay in customer care for a while and I will apply to some internal position when it becomes available”, but you’re wrong. To apply for a position in a different department you have to be in the company for at least 1 year and a half and you have to have very high performances within your role (which is kind of difficult to get recognized for, if you’re not cool). But of course there are exceptional cases, it’s just not clear what is the criteria there, it’s like a leap of faith, you have to believe. In fact, apparently rules do not apply to everyone in Yahoo as I recently witnessed with my own eyes a person getting promoted to another department after less than one year. They say they made an exception. They just didn’t say why.
I’ve never felt so belittled as I did while working in Yahoo!
I don’t recommend this company, at least not the customer care department in Dublin. Unless you’re cool. Then it’s fine.
Advice to Management: Try not to be biased by personal sympathies.

Title: "Strong developers, some very clever people in the ranks, but poor leadership."
Pros: The culture is great in the London office, there's good opportunity for professional growth including encouragement to go to many conferences and to experiment with new technologies and ideas, and some great perks. Many of the developers are incredibly smart.
Cons: The company is focused around the head office in California, to the point where they can't imagine anyone contributing from outside. And there's a very heavy-handed technical leadership who try to micromanage every process of all teams.
Advice to Management:
Give people the freedom to use the best tools for them to do their job, not the best tools for Yahoo's leadership. If you have to force people to use something, look at why people resist so much and consider if that product really is going to help them do their job. If you need all employees to dogfood something, to the point where you can't cope with the level of feedback, then something is very wrong in that product's development process.

Also be aware that most of the technical talent in the world isn't in Silicon Valley and maybe doesn't want to go there - having a lot of financial and emotional investment in other development offices in other regions, or even allowing people to work from home, would be a massive benefit to Yahoo.

Title: "Free food & excellent benefits, poor management and unfair reviews"
Pros:
* Free food
* Above average compensation (but yearly increase % is minuscule), stock options, employee stock purchase plan, etc.
* Free mobile phone
* Commuters/gym benefits, etc.
* Incredible technology stack (both software and hardware) to play with.
Cons:
* Poor management, for instance, you have non-technical and/or inexperienced managers leading teams of engineers. Middle managements block the flow of information from the top. Progress reports only go one way -- from the bottom to the top. You never know what your managers are doing.
* Zero opportunity for promotion and recognition unless you suck up to the manager and he gives you a nice QPR rating. It doesn't matter how talented you are and what you contributed to the team. As long as you are a smooth talker and can kiss the manager's rear end, you're in good shape.
* QPR leads to favoritism and low moral. Team mates are now competing against each other instead of collaborating and sharing ideas.
* Repetitive weekly status update meetings. I thought Marissa told the entire org no status update meetings. You spend more time preparing for meetings than actually doing your work.
* Low pay % increases - don't expect to get a salary increase for the hard work done.
* Despite efforts to improve execution, decision making is still as slow as a crawling turtle.
Advice to Management:
* Get rid of all the useless meetings
* Get rid of the stack ranking system and do REAL performance reviews based on the quality of the work done and contribution to the org.
* Allow individual contributors to anonymously rate their managers, either a pass or fail grade. If the manager fails, he gets demoted and the senior management must take action to find a suitable person that fits the role.

Pros: Work culture is superb. Lots of avenues for expressing creativity. Was quite open and transparent in the beginning (about 7 years ago). CEO talks of transparency, but there is hardly any. People are not involved in much decision making.
There is no passion for the product or for the customer. It's all about delivery delivery and delivery.
Tech Pulse has just become a show of strength now rather than a platform for innovation.

Senior leadership is little or absent. It's like a captainless boat swaying to the winds that blow from Sunnyvale.
They try too hard to monetize everything, and all monetization is mostly about ads. No emphasis on products or user experience (UX has degraded from iteration to iteration).

Title: "loved working there, ambitious company, nice people, nice culture, great benefits"
Pros:
Strives for greatness and turn-around. Dynamic sector brings a lot of movement and changes.
Awesome CEO who does the right thing to motivate people and crowdsource ideas
Some good products which are getting better. Nice mobile products.
People are mostly smart, nice and collaborative.
Perks are great.
Cons:
Ad tech stack (i.e. the money making machine) is well behind the market, which is a shame for a technological company that has strong technical ressources.
Tough competitive landscape.
Some managers have been there for too long and do not have the fresh perspective or technical competency to bring proper changes. Or on the contrary, the c-suite is pushing down the wrong focus with poor knowledge of what is happening in the field and how markets differ.
Advice to Management: Yahoo sucks for a lot of people, especially young tech-aware internet-savvy users but at the same time a lot of people like it or love it. Like former CEO Bartz said "actualy most people outside the east and west coast love the product". This is just how things are and is relatively unique dichotomy. In that regards, it feels sometime that current management does not really understand the user base and does not manage the company to its strengths, i.e. the company has the best (ad) performing audience amongst all other big online media players, loyal as well because adverse to change, not eager to try disruptively new things but open to small new explorations of what the internet has to offer, wishing to stay in a technological confort zone, open and receptive to ads if not fooled by poor quality campaigns and shady advertisers. Trying to be like Google and frustrating its older and loyal users, the company has focused on changing products drastically and bringing new users before focusing on nurturing the existing base and bringing up the performance of their ad inventory. Increasing yield by 10% is much easier then increasing user base by 10%...at least by getting modern ad tech. This was typicaly exemplified by mail product manager claiming "you'd need to kick the users in the balls to have them leave the platform" (see business insider article) and by the fact that focus has been openly on increasing user base via better product rather then improving the outdated ad tech and ad user experience. Management is almost too smart and too silicon valleyish, googler point-of-view has some benefits in terms of bringing technological advances but does not seem in phase with the core of the product. So all-in-all my advice is: focus on getting best in-class ad tech products, hire a non-tech FMCG product manager from the south/midwest, understand how 30+ year old people use the internet outside of San Francisco, open a small office in Africa and get your big user growth, next big innovation and long-term perspective from there (as well as India/SEA), build your new young audiences on other platform / brand (e.g. Tumblr) while nurturing your current users.

Advice to Management: Get off your chairs and let people do some work. It's for the org ultimately.

Cons: Roles at every level are very restricted & constrained due to the sheer size of the company. 'Performance Management' is on going process & this ups the pressure to constantly be on top of your game - it can be a good thing & a bad thing... if you get fired! Career growth is very bleak unless you are on the engineering, products or management teams.
Advice to Management:
Try to lessen the pressure you put on the work force under the label of "Performance Management' so that employees will actually want to stay & work instead of quit in fear of being let go.
Give everybody a raise. Considering the work volume & pressure after so many people were cut & hiring was frozen, we deserve a raise! You would have the money to do so if you didn't go around acquiring every company you set your beady eyes on.
Train the mid level mangers to be transparent at all costs!
Provide avenues for career growth for those who are not part of engineering or product teams!

Even if you survive layoffs for some reason, there is concept of QPR where manager's are forced from upper management to give less ratings. Because of which internally politics will be there. In the name of QPR they laid off so many people.
I still thought to stay back in yahoo as I haven't completed 1 year at Yahoo!. Let me talk about my journey in Yahoo.
I joined Yahoo in June. In the month of Oct/Nov I had a 1-1 with my manager he say's "Please start looking out". I was shocked and asked him why? He says team is moving from India to US. Since I haven't completed a year in Yahoo! he can't transfer me to US. I asked him about internal team transfer he says not possible.

I started looking for internal team transfer also job search outside. Next week my manager comes back and say's I am transferring you to US please stop your job search.
Again next week he say's "Start searching outside". I started searching for internal team transfer . Lucky found some openings . But the new team manager says there is no vision for this division after 1 quarter. I can't promise anything

About my QPR, my manager write's in QPR " My biggest weakness is I should handle org restructing smoothly even if there were so many confusion" --> How funny is that :P

Yes finally I reached my goal I completed a year n moved out of Yahoo!. Yes for sure must say I learn't a lot from Yahoo. How to have patience in life. :) :) :)
Advice to Management: Please don't hire people if you wan't to fire them. It would be very hard for people to convince why job search < 1 year.

Title: "Challenges in Yahoo!"
Pros:
1. Opportunities to work in many exciting new technology. There's an incorrect perception that Y! is not innovating sufficiently; but this is an incorrect perception. This perception is motivated by challenges in execution & ability to drive a new innovation to market.
2. Great diversity. Y! still has many opportunity to work with people from different parts of the world.
Cons:
1. Too many turf issues among middle management, especially among Dir & VP. These wars result in inability to innovate & execute.
2. Lack of accountability. There's no penalty for failures, thus it has become a culture where result is not important anymore.
3. Too perception driven. Talents with capability but poor people skills, are never promoted, resulting in loss of valuable talents and a culture where employees care more about good people relationship than delivering user stunning innovations.
Advice to Management:
Two top priorities:
a. Change culture to result oriented vs perception oriented
b. Less turf wars

Title: "I actually look forward to going to work every day!"
Pros: First, I like working at Yahoo! because I get to see the results of my work in use by millions of people every day. By and large I think most of my fellow Yahoo!s really do work hard to live the company's values and truly love what they do. In the ranks of employees that I usually work with, the spirit of collaboration and willingness to share knowledge rule over all else, and being part of the solution rather than simply restating or avoiding the problem are things they excel at. I have experience in banking, financial services, healthcare, and consulting so I have a wide range of companies to compare my impressions to. After all of this time - some of it with companies considere among the very best of the best in their industries - Yahoo! is the first company I have worked with during my twenty year career where I wake up on most days and actually look forward to going to the office!
Cons:
Of course there are challenges with working at a large company, such as lengthy decision-making processes and too much beauracracy, or senior managers who know - by choice or by ignorance - very little about how to really get things done or manage anything very effectively. But I have found these people at every company I have ever worked with. Yahoo! is no different, except that perhaps there is less of that here. No one should expect any company to be perfectly free from incompetence. Few companies I know can say they don't have a fair share of poor managers sprinked throughout their ranks, who seem to last far longer than they should.

Given this, I think that the management team at Yahoo! is doing a decent job of holding things together in light of changes at the very top of the organization, and a significant amount of reshuffling and re-prioritization of projects needed to return our focus to things that will result in long-term value creation. It may be that these changes came too late, but there have been very positive developments, internally, over the last six to nine months.

Unfortunately, this message is not getting across to shareholders and the public in spite of numerous attempts to offer proof that things have changed (for some reason - maybe it's like the boy who cried "Wolf!"?). And this is the only caution I would throw to anyone thinking of working here. The recent M&A-oriented publicity and Icahn's corporate raider trouble-making has posed more of a threat and distraction for us and our shareholders than Google's business model. That we are still delivering anything is something of a testament to management's ability to keep us focused on what we've been hired to do, for sure, but it is much more likely that we're still at it because most Yahoo! employees really care about their work and love this company.
Advice to Management: Stay focused on delivering value-creating projects and funding those initiatives that show the highest probability for delivering results. Stand by your decisions and stand up for what's best for our stakeholders - including our shareholders, but also our users, advertisers, resellers, channel partners, and employees - and we will win.

Title: "Nothing special"
Pros: “The best reason to work at Yahoo! is very simple: the people who work there. I haven't worked before at a place with so many bright, genuine, and good people. Many of them I now consider friends, some very close friends, and feel genuine loss when I see them leave. The daily interactions with my co-workers are the primary reason I have stayed with Yahoo! so long. In addition, the company offers a broad spectrum of products and projects, and allows a decent flexibility to switch between teams or projects. That is if one is inclined to do so. It has definitely helped me broaden my scope of experience, while still feeling excited and engaged about new opportunities.”
Cons: “The organization still feels very convoluted and there is little visibility into the decision making process, at least in many teams, certainly not all. In general, my experience has been that most decisions are made in and by the "Product" team, which also likes to call themselves "Product Owners." It has always struck me as odd to operate in such a way, since the company is thriving to be an innovator. It begs the question if it shouldn't be the talented people who work there to make the right product decisions. The "Product Team" should be the sum of the people working on a project, with shared ownership and responsibilities. It is one of those details I have always found the most limiting and frustrating in delivering a great experience for the many Yahoo! users out there.”
Advice to Management: “My advice to senior management would be to focus more on their job, while I will focus on mine and deliver as best as I can. Ideally, senior management should be focused on appropriately staffing and budgeting business opportunities and ensuring the right people are doing their job. All too often I found senior management engaged on a level of detail that was overbearing. In the end it slows everything down and leads to products that were designed, not by the most qualified people, but rather by those who mostly interested in their personal career benefits and catering to some people in senior management. Again, this is certainly not the rule, but something one will be able to observe when staying at Yahoo! for some time.”

Title: "Yahoo! Good place to work in, but management needs improvement!!"
Pros:
The work environment is the best and good for innovation and work.
Work environment is kept open and the management takes are of being open and of a joyful nature. The career oppurtunity in Yahoo! is tremendous, if we look at th way we are growing in certain areas. This develops a good environment, as personal growth is also given time for the individual. Compensation and perks are also great, we have facilities like pick and drop from the home and also a work from home culture, which lets us do our personal work, if required. Recognition in the form of awards is also a good way to check the progress of the person. Top management recognizes you for good work done, when it does proliferate up from the leads and the manager.
Cons:
Communication between the teams and a rising insecurity within the members of what will happen.
The environment induces a feeling of well being and gives us time to innovate and relax, the only problem being that due to the realse cycles being too short and not enough staff trained to keep up with the same, it tends to become a place where the innovation is stifled. Only some whose projects are not active make the innovation. While the rest of the people are given away to obscurity. This is a practise which makes the people feel that they are not actually working on what they wish to and make them dull. Instead of being productive, they start to become unproductive in the short run itself. Awards have started getting too politically motivated and go to those who know how to market themselves and not to the exact deserving candidates. Due to the influx required to fill places, we have started lowering the standards at which we choose candidates. This should not be done anytime, as it will start getting more undeserving candidates, who are more interested in the perks rather than the work.
Advice to Management: Please be more communicative. Also, try and build an environment of sharing within the teams, instead of keeping things hidden from one team to the next. Duplicacy and waste of time is the only thing that ensues from this. Also, keep the rewards and compensation system transparent so that there is no resentment in the engineerings as to why they were not deserving for the same.
